chunks.original_text: 其玄丹宫经，亦真官司命君之要言，四宫之领宗矣。 此一经须太极帝君告，乃与之也，亦时出授耳。 玄丹经即三一后者是也，其本亦出素灵。 按此道高妙，而与三元同卷者，是苏君最末所行以得真卿，故紫阳撰出其事，而载传后耳，本非共一经也。 其盟脆既不同科，受传之时，自可不必与三一俱受，而玄丹经云：旦夕守诸三一讫，乃未存之者，是玄丹家自可得先守一，守一之家不必知玄丹也。 凡合五宫之道行乎世上，有真名者遭值之矣，自非骨相挺命，不闻此言也。 世人有受此道者甚多，而修守之者无一，此身中之神不如他法，上真所宝秘，亦足为业，今此一道若行之则长生，不行则死矣，乃皆非骨挺之谓也。 又有玉帝宫，玉清神母居之； 又有天庭宫，上清真女居之； 又有真极宫，太极帝妃居之； 前谓极真，此云真极，二字上下，未详孰正，恐后或是误耳。 又有太皇宫，太上君后居之。 此四宫皆雌真一也，道高於雄真一也，并有宝经以传已成真人者，未得成真，非所闻也，其雌真之要，亦自不授之矣。 前五宫其神皆男，故谓雄一，此四宫皆女，是为雌一。 凡上清太微中之九宫，则有真君居之，故人头亦设此位以相应耳，所谓虚和可守雄，萧萧可守雌。 萧萧者，单景独往之谓也，在世学虽未成真，胸怀滓滞，故不可修之也。 五千文亦言知其雄，守其雌也。 此四宫人皆有之，但不修此道者，宫中空空耳，夫不尽修於九宫者，宫亦空耳，非但雌家四宫而已。 至於丹田宫中常有帝君，守寸常有大神，不复问须守乃见在宫耳，修之者神仙，不修者以寿死矣。 如此则凡俗庸猥之人，身中亦皆三一常具，但不能修守者，须其人寿毕便去，去即致死。 若所得之法常能修存，则诸空宫之中亦随事受神，非但丹田中一帝君也。 守一不殆，其寿限一过，便无复死期，以至於相见，相见则得道矣。 雄雌一神，男女并可兼修之无在也，唯决精苦之至乃获益矣。 此谓雌雄之一，男女皆可俱修，不分别其男女之异也。 若男人守雌亦为雌形，女子守雄则犹雄状，但三卿是我身中精化所结，当各依本别其男女耳。 守一之理，先宜一二年中精思苦到，须得仿髴，便易为存想也。 守寸为始守一之法。 寻经中序说，前后不相次类附，或始未分乖，或事用超涉，不可都依本宣而写之，今更诠贯次第，钞拔源领，其大字悉是本文所载，不加损益，但条综端绪，令以次依按耳。 以立春之日夜半之时，正坐东向，经后云立夏南向，立秋西向，立冬北向，诀曰此是守三元真一之法，俱用四立之夜，亥时后便可就行事，各向月建，四立则四孟，非正方也，五斗分至乃四仲耳。 各平坐闭气临目握固两膝上，乃先存守寸如法。 两眉间上，其裹有黄阙紫户、绛台青房，共构立守寸之中，左右耳，此即前却入三分之域，台阙於三分之中，两边其广一寸，列於左右，各方三分，令中间开四分为道，内通明堂，上出通天庭前户也。 守寸左面有绛台，台之形状如今城门边方楼，外及上下，皆以赤玉作之，楼上之中有窗户，帷帐并青色，而神居其内。 右面有黄阙。 阙形犹似台，亦正方外通，以黄玉作之，阙上之中有窗户，帷帐并紫色，而神居其内。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Mysterious Cinnabar Palace Scripture* likewise contains the essential teachings of the *True Officials* and the *Minister of Destiny*, serving as the guiding principle of the Four Palaces. This scripture must be bestowed by the *Supreme Ultimate Emperor Lord*, and it is only occasionally transmitted. The *Mysterious Cinnabar Scripture* refers to the practice following the *Three Ones*; its origins also trace back to the *Primordial Numinosity*. Though this Way is profound and wondrous, and though it shares a scroll with the *Three Origins*, it was in fact the final practice of Master Su, through which he attained the rank of *True Minister*. Thus, Master Ziyang compiled its methods and transmitted them afterward—it was never originally part of the same scripture. As their pledges and covenants differ in rank, at the time of transmission, one need not receive the *Three Ones* together with it. Yet the *Mysterious Cinnabar Scripture* states: *"Only after dawn and dusk guarding the various Three Ones is complete may one proceed to the next stage."* This implies that practitioners of the *Mysterious Cinnabar* may first guard the One, while those who guard the One need not know of the *Mysterious Cinnabar*.

When the Ways of the Five Palaces circulate in the world, those with true names may encounter them. Yet without the destined bone and fate, one shall not hear of these teachings. Many in the world receive these methods, but none cultivate and guard them. The deities within the body in this practice differ from those in other methods; they are treasured and concealed by the *Upper Perfected*, and the practice itself is sufficient for one’s work. If one cultivates this Way, one attains long life; if one does not, one dies. Yet this is not a matter of destined bone alone.

There is also the *Jade Emperor Palace*, where the *Jade Clarity Divine Mother* resides; the *Celestial Court Palace*, where the *Upper Clarity True Woman* dwells; the *True Ultimate Palace*, where the *Supreme Ultimate Empress* abides; and previously, it was called *Ultimate Truth*, but here it is named *True Ultimate*—the order of these two characters remains unclear, and it is feared that a later error may have occurred. There is also the *Grand Sovereign Palace*, where the *Supreme Lord’s Queen* resides. These Four Palaces all pertain to the *Feminine True One*, and their Way is higher than that of the *Masculine True One*. Each has its own precious scriptures, transmitted only to those who have already attained *Perfected* rank; those who have not yet achieved *Perfection* shall not hear of them, and their essentials of the *Feminine True* are likewise not bestowed.

The deities of the previous Five Palaces are all male, hence called the *Masculine One*; the deities of these Four Palaces are all female, hence called the *Feminine One*. Among the Nine Palaces of the *Upper Clarity* and *Great Tenuity*, *True Lords* reside, and thus corresponding positions are established in the human head to align with them. It is said: *"In emptiness and harmony, guard the Masculine; in solitude and stillness, guard the Feminine."* *"Solitude and stillness"* refers to solitary wandering in simplicity. Though one may not yet have attained *Perfection* in worldly study, if the mind remains turbid and obstructed, one cannot cultivate this Way. The *Five Thousand Characters* also speak of *"knowing the Masculine, guarding the Feminine."*

These Four Palaces exist within all people, but those who do not cultivate this Way leave their palaces empty. Those who do not fully cultivate the Nine Palaces likewise leave their palaces empty—not only the Four Palaces of the *Feminine*. Within the *Cinnabar Field Palace*, the *Emperor Lord* is always present; within the *Inch of Guarding*, great deities constantly reside. One need not wait to guard them to find them already in their palaces. Those who cultivate become *Immortals*; those who do not die at the end of their allotted years. Thus, even in the bodies of the vulgar and common, the *Three Ones* are always present. Yet if one cannot cultivate and guard them, when one’s lifespan ends, they depart, and death follows. If the methods one has received are constantly cultivated and preserved, then deities will also enter the empty palaces in accordance with the practice—not only the *Emperor Lord* in the *Cinnabar Field*.

*"Guard the One without fail, and when the limit of one’s lifespan passes, there shall be no further death. Until the time of meeting, when meeting occurs, one attains the Dao."* The deities of the *Masculine* and *Feminine Ones* may be cultivated together by both men and women without distinction. Only through utmost dedication and perseverance shall one gain benefit. This refers to the *Masculine* and *Feminine Ones*: both men and women may cultivate them together, without distinguishing between male and female. If a man guards the *Feminine*, he assumes a feminine form; if a woman guards the *Masculine*, she takes on a masculine appearance. However, the *Three Ministers* are formed from the essence of one’s own body, and thus one should follow one’s original nature and distinguish between male and female.

The principle of *guarding the One* first requires one or two years of focused and arduous contemplation, until one attains a semblance of realization, making visualization easier. *Guarding the Inch* is the initial method of *guarding the One*. Examining the prefaces and sequences in the scriptures, the order is not always consistent, with some sections initially undivided, others surpassing conventional usage. One cannot transcribe them strictly according to their original presentation. Here, I have arranged and connected them in proper sequence, extracting their essentials and sources. The large characters are all from the original text, without addition or omission; I have merely organized their threads to allow for orderly reference.

On the night of *Beginning of Spring*, at midnight, sit facing east. The scripture later states: on *Beginning of Summer*, face south; on *Beginning of Autumn*, face west; on *Beginning of Winter*, face north. The method states: this is the practice of *guarding the Three Origins True One*, all using the nights of the four *Beginnings* (of the seasons). After the *Hai* hour (9–11 p.m.), one may proceed, facing the *Monthly Establishment*. The four *Beginnings* correspond to the four *First Months* of the seasons, not the cardinal directions; the *Five Dippers* divide the *Solstices* and *Equinoxes*, which are the four *Middle Months*.

Sit evenly, hold the breath, close the eyes, clench the fists, and place them on the knees. First, visualize *guarding the Inch* according to the method. Above the space between the eyebrows, within, there is the *Yellow Gate*, *Purple Chamber*, *Crimson Terrace*, and *Azure House*, all together forming the domain of *guarding the Inch*. Behind the ears, this is the region three *fen* inward. The *Terrace* and *Gate* lie within these three *fen*, with a width of one *cun* on each side, each three *fen* square, leaving a central opening of four *fen* as a path, internally connecting to the *Hall of Light* and ascending to the front gate of the *Celestial Court*.

On the left side of *guarding the Inch* is the *Crimson Terrace*. The terrace’s form resembles a square tower beside a city gate, with its exterior and upper and lower parts all made of red jade. In the center of the tower’s upper section is a window, with curtains and hangings all in azure, and the deity resides within. On the right side is the *Yellow Gate*. The gate’s form is similar to the terrace, also square and open externally, made of yellow jade. In the center of the gate’s upper section is a window, with curtains and hangings all in purple, and the deity resides within.

Though said to be transmitted, it has never been seen in the world. Thus, the *Central Lord* said: *"Only those who toil tirelessly shall I grant the Flowing Pearl Truth."* This is the supreme Way of the *Central Truth*, though these words seem addressed to a guest, and it remains unclear whether it was ever received.

chunks.original_text: 其九宫真人出入，皆从黄阙、绛台中间为道，故以道之左右置台阙者，以司非常之气，伺迎真人之往来也。 此是说耳，非存思事也。 头中九宫真神出入之所由，外虽有上帝信命，不得即前，故二神常握铃守卫，犹如今城门之防也。 方诸洞房云，紫户入者谓斗星，从其中间入洞房中，非止从黄阙、紫户之内偏入也，盖举其一名耳。 九宫皆各有前户后户，以相通洞上四宫，从天庭前出，仍下守寸台阙裹面出於外，唯泥丸一宫有下门，以通喉中，与中下两宫相关也。 紫户大神名平静，字法王，在右边者。 青房大神名正心，字切方，在左边者。 此二神皆居房户之内，故不以台阙为号。 形并如婴孩，如婴儿始生之状，玉色，而坐常相向也。 各服衣如其房户之色，右边紫，左边青，皆幔帛，非锦也。 手执流金铃，各执一铃，两手共把之，流金铃即火铃也。 无质而赤光。 状如火焖之形。
chunks.translated_text:
The Nine Palaces’ Perfected Ones enter and exit through the path between the Yellow Gate and the Crimson Terrace. Thus, the placement of the terrace and gate to the left and right of the Way is to govern the qi of the extraordinary, awaiting and receiving the Perfected Ones’ comings and goings. This is merely an explanation, not a matter of meditative visualization.

The paths by which the Perfected Spirits of the Nine Palaces enter and exit the head—though there be the Celestial Sovereign’s trusted mandate without, they may not approach directly. Thus, these two spirits constantly grasp bells to stand guard, much like the defenses of a city gate.

As the *Dongfang of the Square Cauldron* states: “Those who enter through the Purple Door are called the Dipper Stars; they pass through its center to enter the *Dongfang*, not merely through the Yellow Gate or the Purple Door’s inner side.” This refers only to one of its names.

Each of the Nine Palaces has a front and rear door, mutually connecting to the four upper palaces. Exiting from the front of the *Celestial Court*, they descend again to emerge from within the terrace and gate of *guarding the Inch*, then outward. Only the *Mud Pill Palace* has a lower gate, connecting to the throat and linking with the middle and lower palaces.

The great spirit of the Purple Door is named Tranquil Leveling, styled Dharma King, and resides on the right. The great spirit of the Azure Chamber is named Upright Heart, styled Precise Square, and resides on the left. These two spirits dwell within the chamber doors, and thus are not designated by terrace or gate.

Their forms resemble infants, like newborn babes, with jade-like complexions, and they always sit facing one another. Each wears robes matching the color of their chamber door: purple on the right, azure on the left, both of plain silk, not brocade. They hold *flowing-metal bells*—fire bells—grasping one in each hand, two bells held together. The *flowing-metal bells* have no substance but glow red, resembling the shape of smoldering embers.

chunks.original_text: 此二神身中亦有风云之气，焕赫守寸之境。 暮卧及存思之时，若单存诸九宫之夕，初卧亦存祝如此，若值守诸九宫之夜，至临卧存时又先如此。 先存二大神仿髴在见，闭气存思具如前形，既在其宫，便如睹见。 仍三呼其名字，当心呼曰：紫户大神名平静字法王二二二二，青房大神名正心字切方二二二二 。 如此乃通气而微祝曰： 紫户青房，有二大神，手把流铃，身生风云，挟卫真道，不听外前，使我思感，通达灵关，出入利贞，上登九门，即见九真，太上之尊六韵。 祝毕，方乃存思三一洞房九道诸要道也。 九道即九宫之道。 诸单修明堂、洞房、玄丹者，皆先存祝如此。 雌一之妙，亦依此法。 夫头中九宫之位，有二神，则左神为上，乃次右。 有三神者中为上，次左，次右。 存修之始，必从下起，故守寸先紫户，洞房先白元，其明堂先左者，女例贵於男也。 唯丹田帝乡是我身中之精化，非外来之品次，故末乃存之耳。 若非上宫在身下者，则左为上，次中次右也。 明堂 明堂中存守寸毕，次存此。 若不守一，单用此亦佳。 若上守一，不行此亦无嫌，能兼之者益善耳。 左有明童真君，讳玄阳，字少青； 存为男形。 右有明女真君，讳微阴，字少元； 存为女形。 中有明镜神君，讳照精，字四明。 存亦男形。 此三君共治明堂宫，并着锦衣绿色，腰带四玉铃，口衔赤玉镜，镜铃并赤色。 上下同服绿色锦衣，腰带四赤玉铃，前后左右各一，口衔赤玉镜之鼻，镜面向外。 铃镜虽有质而赤光照洞，声明焕彻，响映九宫。 头如婴儿，形亦如之，对坐俱向外面，或相向也。 并如始生之形，金光玉色，白日三人俱向外，夜则左右俱向中央。 此明堂之道也。 若守一以次存明堂者，至此便各呼其位号三过。 曰#1明童真君讳玄阳字少青二二二二 ，明女真君讳微阴字少元二二二二，明镜神君讳照精字四明二二二二。 又叩齿九通止，乃次存洞房也。 若非守一之时，止行於后诸事用者，亦先存如此，毕乃各依后法耳。 若道士恐畏，凡云道士者，谓修道之士也，既山居独处，脱有邪魔来犯，及心中不宁，振惧之时，应为此法。 存三神，使呜玉铃，使声闻太极，存三神各以手摇铃，腰带四铃，觉耳闻其声，震动响彻天上太极宫也。 存使吐玉镜赤光，令万丈，亦觉吐镜光於守寸出，照彻四方，圆绕各五十里，一百六十六步四尺，凡所住处当先步四面周匝，至某山某村某界域，令得合此数后，存光之时，使鲦然至此而止则易也。 每事皆须精旨如此，不但斯一法而已。 存之俱毕，因三呼三君名字，叩齿九通，则千妖伏息，万鬼灭形也。 存毕呼名位，如前以次云云也。 此一条是制却邪精众妖之法。 若道士饮渴，此谓渴於饮也，亦或应是饥渴字。 亦存三君并口吐赤气使灌己口，口因吸而咽之，须臾自饱也。 此当存吐赤气於守寸中，郁郁然下入我口，口乃吸取吞咽无数，行吐行咽，以饱为度，此一条是止饥渴之法。 若道士夜行暗不见路，又存三君，继前诸事而言，故有文字耳。 使口出三火光照前，须臾路自朗明也。 此亦各吐一赤光，状如火明，从守寸出，列前远照渟彻，存注如似目见，明朗便行，行存行进，勿得休息。 此一条是照暗之法。
chunks.translated_text:
Within these two spirits also reside the qi of wind and clouds, resplendent in guarding the *cun*-realm of the chamber.

When retiring at dusk or engaging in visualization, if one focuses solely on the Nine Palaces in the evening, one should first lie down and visualize accordingly. If it is a night designated for guarding the Nine Palaces, upon nearing the time of visualization, one must first attend to this. Begin by visualizing the two great spirits as if they are present before you. Hold the breath and visualize them in their full form as described earlier. Once they appear within their chambers, it will be as though you see them with your own eyes. Then, call their names and styles three times, intoning at the heart:

*Purple Door Great Spirit, named Tranquil Leveling, styled Dharma King—two, two, two, two; Azure Chamber Great Spirit, named Upright Heart, styled Precise Square—two, two, two, two.*

Thereafter, regulate the breath and softly intone the incantation:

*Purple Door, Azure Chamber,
Two great spirits stand,
Hands grasp flowing bells,
Bodies birth wind and clouds.
They escort and guard the true Dao,
Bar entry to all without.
Let my thoughts and perceptions
Pierce through the numinous gates,
Exiting and entering with upright harmony,
Ascending through the Nine Portals,
To behold the Nine Perfected,
The honored of the Supreme High—six verses.*

Once the incantation is complete, proceed to visualize the Three Ones, the Cavern Chamber, the Nine Paths, and all essential Dao-paths. The Nine Paths are the paths of the Nine Palaces.

All who practice visualization of the Bright Hall, Cavern Chamber, or Mysterious Cinnabar alone must first perform this visualization and incantation. The marvel of the Feminine One also follows this method.

Within the Nine Palaces of the head, if there are two spirits, the left is superior, followed by the right. If there are three spirits, the center is superior, followed by the left, then the right. At the outset of visualization practice, one must begin from the lower regions. Thus, when guarding the *cun*-realm, one first attends to the Purple Door; when visualizing the Cavern Chamber, one first attends to White Prime; and when visualizing the Bright Hall, one begins with the left—this follows the principle that the feminine is esteemed above the masculine. Only the Cinnabar Field and Imperial Homeland are transformations of the essence within one’s own body, not ranks of external origin, and thus are visualized last. If the upper palace is not located below the body, then the left is superior, followed by the center, then the right.

**Bright Hall**
After completing the visualization of the *cun*-realm, proceed to this. If one does not practice the Guarding of the One, using this method alone is also excellent. If one primarily guards the One, omitting this is not amiss, though practicing both is even better.

On the left resides the Bright Youth Perfected Lord, whose tabooed name is Mysterious Yang and whose style is Lesser Azure. Visualize him in male form. On the right resides the Bright Maiden Perfected Lord, whose tabooed name is Subtle Yin and whose style is Lesser Prime. Visualize her in female form. In the center resides the Bright Mirror Spirit Lord, whose tabooed name is Illuminating Essence and whose style is Fourfold Clarity. Visualize him also in male form. These three lords jointly govern the Bright Hall Palace. All wear brocade robes of green, with belts adorned with four jade bells, and hold in their mouths a red jade mirror. Both the mirrors and bells are red. Their attire is uniformly green brocade robes, with belts bearing four red jade bells—one each at front, back, left, and right—and they hold in their mouths the nose of the red jade mirror, its surface facing outward. Though the bells and mirrors have substance, their red glow illuminates all, their brilliance resounding and reverberating through the Nine Palaces. Their heads resemble those of infants, as do their forms, and they sit facing outward or toward one another. All appear as newborns, with golden radiance and jade-like complexions. By day, the three face outward; by night, the left and right turn toward the center. Such is the Dao of the Bright Hall.

If one practices the Guarding of the One followed by the visualization of the Bright Hall, at this point call out the titles and names of each three times:

*Bright Youth Perfected Lord, whose tabooed name is Mysterious Yang, styled Lesser Azure—two, two, two, two;
Bright Maiden Perfected Lord, whose tabooed name is Subtle Yin, styled Lesser Prime—two, two, two, two;
Bright Mirror Spirit Lord, whose tabooed name is Illuminating Essence, styled Fourfold Clarity—two, two, two, two.*

Then, click the teeth nine times and cease, proceeding next to visualize the Cavern Chamber. If one is not practicing the Guarding of the One and intends to perform only the subsequent methods, one must first visualize thus, completing it before proceeding to the remaining practices.

If a Daoist—here referring to one who cultivates the Dao—fears or dreads anything, such as dwelling alone in the mountains and encountering malevolent spirits or disturbances of the heart, or experiencing tremors of apprehension, one should employ this method. Visualize the three spirits, causing them to ring their jade bells, so that the sound reaches the Great Ultimate. Visualize the three spirits each shaking the bells at their waists, the four bells, so that the ears perceive their sound, resounding and reverberating through the Celestial Palace of the Great Ultimate. Visualize them exhaling the red glow of their jade mirrors, extending ten thousand *zhang*, also perceiving the light of the mirrors emanating from the *cun*-realm, illuminating the four directions in a circle of fifty *li*, one hundred sixty-six *bu*, and four *chi*. One should first pace the perimeter of one’s dwelling, marking the boundaries to a specific mountain, village, or domain, so that when visualizing the light, it naturally extends to this limit, making the practice easier. Every matter requires such precision, not merely this one method.

Once the visualization is complete, call the names and titles of the three lords three times, clicking the teeth nine times. Then, a thousand demons will be subdued, and ten thousand ghosts will vanish. After completing the visualization, call their names and titles in sequence as before.

This section describes the method for repelling evil spirits and myriad demons.

If a Daoist experiences thirst—here referring to thirst for drink, though it may also denote hunger and thirst—visualize the three lords exhaling red qi into one’s mouth, which one then inhales and swallows, soon feeling sated. One should visualize them exhaling red qi from the *cun*-realm, which descends thickly into one’s mouth. One then inhales and swallows it repeatedly, until fully sated. This is the method for alleviating hunger and thirst.

If a Daoist travels at night and cannot see the path, again visualize the three lords, continuing from the previous methods. Cause them to exhale three beams of fiery light to illuminate the way ahead, and soon the path will become bright and clear. Each should exhale a red glow, like a flame, emerging from the *cun*-realm and extending far ahead to illuminate the surroundings. Visualize this as vividly as if seen with the eyes, and the path will become bright. Proceed while maintaining the visualization, without pause. This is the method for illuminating darkness.

chunks.original_text: 若行凶处危难之中，有刀兵之地，既未能坐在立亡，及远窜无人之乡，世事多虞，忽有危急，则无以禳卫，故显此法，至於世人精向者，亦可行之，所以独无道士之目也。 急存三君，使呜玉铃，精而想之，存各奋四铃，振赤镜光，以掩击敌人及凶恶之处，觉令彼甲遇此光皆即顿仆也。 敌人自然心骇意慑，不复生割心也。 割谓割夺之割，亦可应作害字。 此一条是辟却凶恶之法 若道士欲求延年不死，疾病临困求救而生者，当正安寝，偃卧握固，闭气暝目定心，先仿髴存日月在明堂中，日左月右，存三君如上法。 存明堂三君，并向外长跪。 夜存亦令向外也，此人形既卧，神亦随偃，而尚长跪状如立时。 凡身中之神有卧，而存者於此为明，犹如守寸台阙，岂容回转，故自附形而侧矣，然要应作坐想也。 口吐赤气使光贯我身令匝，各吐赤镜光气，从守寸中出，渐渐绕身。 我口傍咽赤气，唯多无数，当闭目微咽之也，随吸取所贯之赤气而咽之，唯觉勃勃入口，下流胸腹。 须臾赤气绕身者变成火，火因烧身，身与火共作一体，内外洞光，良久乃止。 状似拘魂之法，使火通烧身表裹骨肉，如然炭之状乃佳。 名曰日月炼形，死而更生者也。 此当初遇疾病，即宜作此法治之。 若方待困笃，恐存想不复能精，微觉便速修行。 此一条是治病消疾之道，行之无的时节也。 又暮卧为之，则必长年不死也。 谓夕夕为之，以求延年，既非高法，故止不死而已，亦小道可观者矣。 此一条是兼修行长生之法，即明堂家常用之道也。 又数存咽赤气，使人颜色反少，色如童子，此不死之道。 谓非治疾，及暮卧存想之时，亦常宜存咽赤气，亦存三君口吐，从守寸中出，下入我口，乃咽之耳。 此一条是还童之道矣。 明常之要毕矣。
chunks.translated_text:
If one finds oneself in perilous circumstances—amidst treacherous terrain, the chaos of armed conflict, or when neither concealment nor flight to desolate lands can avert worldly dangers—should sudden crisis strike and no means of warding or defense remain, this method is revealed. Even those among the laity who are devout may practice it, for it is not reserved solely for Daoists.

In haste, visualize the Three Lords and cause them to sound jade bells. Focus intently and imagine each Lord brandishing four bells, shaking forth beams of crimson mirror-light to strike and repel enemies or malevolent forces. Upon encountering this radiance, their armor shall falter, and they will collapse at once. The adversaries, stricken with terror, will no longer harbor thoughts of harm—*harm* here meaning violent seizure, though it may also be read as *injury*. This is the method for repelling evil and danger.

If a Daoist seeks to prolong life and escape death, or when illness strikes and deliverance is sought, one should lie down properly, supine with fists clenched, hold the breath, close the eyes, and settle the mind. First, faintly visualize the sun and moon within the Hall of Light, the sun to the left and the moon to the right. Then, as in the previous methods, visualize the Three Lords. Within the Hall of Light, the Three Lords should be seen kneeling upright and facing outward—even at night, they must be visualized as facing outward. Though the body lies prone, the spirits follow its repose yet remain in the posture of long kneeling, as if standing. For while the gods within the body may recline, the visualization here must remain clear, just as the *cun*-realm’s terrace and watchtower admit no turning aside. Thus, though they align with the body’s position, they must be imagined as seated.

Exhale red qi, causing its light to envelop the body in a full circuit. Each Lord emits beams of crimson mirror-light from the *cun*-realm, gradually encircling the body. Near the mouth, swallow the red qi repeatedly, without limit. With eyes closed, gently draw in the encircling red qi and swallow it, sensing its vigorous descent into the mouth and onward through the chest and abdomen. Soon, the red qi encircling the body transforms into fire, which then burns the body until flesh and flame become one, radiating luminous brilliance within and without. This continues for a long while, resembling the method of restraining the hun-soul, as the fire thoroughly scorches the body’s exterior and interior, bones and flesh, until they glow like burning charcoal. This is called the *Refining of the Form through Sun and Moon*, whereby the dead are revived.

When illness first strikes, this method should be employed to cure it. If one waits until the affliction has grown severe, the visualization may no longer be precise, so practice it at the first sign of discomfort. This is the Way to heal sickness and dispel illness, and there is no fixed time for its practice. If performed every evening before sleep, it will assuredly grant long life and prevent death. For though it is not a lofty method—merely ensuring immortality—it remains a minor Way worthy of attention. This is also the method for cultivating longevity through concurrent practice, a common technique among those who tend the Hall of Light.

Furthermore, by frequently visualizing and swallowing red qi, one’s complexion will revert to youth, becoming like that of a child. This is the Way to avoid death. Even when not treating illness or engaging in evening visualization, one should regularly visualize and swallow red qi, imagining the Three Lords exhaling it from the *cun*-realm into one’s mouth before swallowing. This is the Way to return to youth.

Herein lie the essentials of the Bright and Constant Way.

chunks.original_text: 凡此明堂之事，乃有七条，皆备尽诸法，唯通无祝辞一事，按常真之道，亦是明堂家法，而存祝殊为委曲，又恐明堂别有太经，此传中盖是钞略耳。 旦起，皆咽液三十过，以手拭面摩目以为常，存液作赤津液。 此一条以犹配明堂家事。 有皆字者，谓行明堂延年之法，旦旦皆应如此耳，亦可兼是守一家用，虽通两法，同为一行耳。 .洞房 又当兼行洞房，从守寸、明堂，便次洞房，乃得丹田，故谓宜兼行，不得略度於中间也。 洞房之中，自有黄阙紫户玄精之室，身中三一尊君常栖息处所也。 此黄阙紫户，非谓守寸者也，是洞房宫中别自有之，犹如玄丹云紫房绿室耳。 上一帝君亦时入其中，玉字所存是也，中下两一不得栖游，此言三一，举其纲会，且尊君之称，亦止谓帝君是三一之尊者矣。 兼行之者，见一神益速也。 所存既多，故致感亦速也。 洞房真人须守一为根本，从外至内，缘始及终，根本之来，由一而起。 守一真人须洞房为华盖，光仪覆荫，以成其道。 故三一相须，洞房相待，虽其居不同，而致道用者须齐也。 九宫之道，乃宫宫各用，至於兼修，则多多益善，事旨既殊，不相妨碍，但患经难备晓，而诚易厌替，是以学者比肩，未有得其尘毫者矣。 洞房中有三真，左为无英公子，右为白元君，中为黄老君，三人共治洞房中，此飞真之道，别自有经。 按此三真是洞房之常神，而九真乃使假化，离合白元、无英，合为一真。 又白元在肺，不入洞房，且方诸玉字，止黄老一君而已。 登真隐诀卷上竟 #1『曰』字上疑有脱文。 登真隐诀卷中
chunks.translated_text:
Herein lie the seven essentials of the Hall of Light, encompassing all methods in their entirety. Only the matter of unspoken invocations remains—though by the standards of the Constant and True Way, this too belongs to the Hall of Light’s tradition, the visualization of invocations is particularly intricate. It is feared that the Hall of Light may possess other grand scriptures, and what is transmitted here is but an abridged excerpt.

Each morning upon rising, one should swallow saliva thirty times, then wipe the face and massage the eyes as a regular practice, visualizing the saliva as crimson fluid. This single method may yet serve as a complement to the Hall of Light’s practices.

The phrase "in all cases" indicates that those who practice the Hall of Light’s method for extending life should perform this daily without fail. It may also be employed by those who cultivate the *shouyi* (Guardian of Unity) tradition, for though these are two distinct methods, they converge in a single practice.

The *Dongfang* (Cavern Chamber) must also be cultivated in tandem. Proceeding from the *cun*-realm and the Hall of Light, one then enters the *Dongfang* to reach the *Dantian* (Cinnabar Field). Thus, it is fitting to practice both together, without omitting any stage in between.

Within the *Dongfang* lie the Yellow Gate, the Purple Portal, and the Chamber of Mysterious Essence—abodes where the Three Ones, the Venerable Lords, perpetually reside. These Yellow Gate and Purple Portal are not the same as those in the *cun*-realm but exist separately within the *Dongfang* Palace, akin to the Mysterious Elixir’s Purple Chamber and Verdant Chamber.

The Supreme Lord of the Upper One occasionally enters this realm, where the Jade Scriptures are stored. The Middle and Lower Ones are not permitted to wander here. When referring to the Three Ones, this is a general designation, and the title "Venerable Lord" applies only to the Supreme Lord as the most exalted of the Three.

Those who practice both methods together will perceive the deities more swiftly, for the more one visualizes, the quicker the resonance. The *Dongfang* adept must take *shouyi* as their foundation, progressing from external to internal, from beginning to end, for the root of all cultivation arises from the One.

The *shouyi* adept must take the *Dongfang* as their canopy of radiance, its luminous majesty sheltering and perfecting their Way. Thus, the Three Ones and the *Dongfang* are interdependent: though their dwellings differ, those who attain the Way must harmonize their practice.

The Way of the Nine Palaces employs each palace individually, yet in concurrent cultivation, the more one engages, the greater the benefit. Though their principles differ, they do not obstruct one another. The difficulty lies in the scarcity of accessible scriptures and the ease with which sincerity wanes, which is why scholars, though numerous, have scarcely grasped even a fraction of its essence.

Within the *Dongfang* reside three perfected beings: on the left, the Lordless Lad; on the right, the White Prime Lord; and in the center, the Yellow Elder Lord. Together, they govern the *Dongfang*, and this is the Way of Ascending Perfection, which has its own separate scriptures.

These three perfected beings are the constant deities of the *Dongfang*, while the Nine Perfected are transient manifestations. They separate and reunite the White Prime and the Lordless Lad, coalescing into a single perfected being. Moreover, the White Prime resides in the lungs and does not enter the *Dongfang*. Thus, according to the Jade Scriptures, only the Yellow Elder Lord remains.

*Dengzhen Yinjue*, Scroll the Upper, concludes.
*(Note: The character 「曰」 above appears to mark a possible lacuna.)*
*Dengzhen Yinjue*, Scroll the Middle.

chunks.original_text: 云林夫人曰：夜卧先急闭目，东向，按后云要当以生气时者，则初夕之卧不得行此，至子以后卧觉，使起坐为之，日中之前皆可数按祝耳，但虑东向，不随四时也。 以手大指后掌，各左右按拭目就耳门，使两掌俱交会於项中三九过，此近掌后，从大指边起，先微按目有云，仍各左右拭目，摩耳门过，交於项后，如此更还，三九乃止。 存目中各有紫、青、绛三色气出目前。 此是内按三素云以灌合童子也。 向按时，存三色云光郁郁，各出面上，至三九过讫，小停住，以疑运三气，使晖灌眼童，乃复为之。 阴祝曰： 眼童三云，两目真君，英明注精，开通清神，太玄云仪，灵娇翩翩，保利双阙，启彻九门，百节应响，朝液泥丸，身升玉宫，列为上真六韵。 祝毕，因咽液五十过，毕乃开目以为常。 坐起可行之，不必夜也，要当以生气时。 一年许，耳目便精明，久为之，彻视千里，罗映神灵，听於绝响者也。 此亦真仙之高道，不但明目开耳而已，我沧浪方丈仙人常宝而为之。 此道出太上四明王经中，传行以金青为誓，然后乃施行耳。 寻耳目之道，莫妙此法，故立盟约乃得传用。 凡诸修守存祝之事，亦皆应脆誓玄师，不尔无验，金青多少在人之意耳。 右云林告杨书。 一面之上，常欲得两手摩拭之，使热，高下随形，皆使极匝。 先当摩切两掌令热，然后以拭面目，毕又顺手发而理栉之状，两臂亦更互以手摩之。 此存法，昼夜有闲便为之，先摩掌及热，以摩面目数遍，复切掌又摩，如此四五过，乃度手项后及两鬓，更互摩鬓，向上就经，状如栉头，数十过止，此法虽解童颜还白之良方也。 此而字即训如字用也。 右出丹景经中，令人面有光泽，皱斑不生，发不白，脉不浮外，行之五年，色如少女，所谓山川行气，常盈不没。 此即下品丹景道精经中所言，谓常如山川行气，常得充满而木石荣润矣。 长史书。 卧起，不必早卧起，凡卧初起，皆可为之。 当平气定气，令呼吸徐微也，正坐，随月王向方面，先叉两手，叉手而反之，极伸臂於前。 乃度以掩项后，因仰面视上，兴项，使举两手，手争为之三四止。 兴犹起也，谓叉手覆掩项竟，仰面起项，作力与争极，复低缓之，如此三四，亦当闻颈骨呜也，此兴字或作与字。 毕，又动屈身体，解手低头屈腰，回转背，脚亦可起倚。 伸手四极，伸举两手於头上，极力散向两边，从前乃复俱向后，仍反张也。 反张侧掣，当先偃腰反张，仍又合手随身，纵体左右，侧掣掉之。 宣摇百关，当复行动振奋，体脚手臂膝经，皆令通匝。 为之各三，如此一事，辄三过为之，乃以此复作，非都遍复始也。 此当口诀。 谓运动四体，不可都书载，当口诀委曲示其形用也，意谓正当如所注耳。 右出大洞真经精景按摩篇，使人精和血通，风气不入，能久行之，不死不病。 此大洞之例，卷题殊多，非谓止在三十九章也，后云大洞精景上卷，又大洞遏邪大祝，如是则皆为不少。 长史书。 卧起，先以手巾若厚帛拭项中四面及耳后，皆使圆匝，温温然也。 顺发摩项，若理栉之无数也，良久摩两手以治面目，都毕，咽液三十过，以导内液。 谓卧初起，先宜向王行此法，竟乃为叉手反诸事也。 右出《大洞精景经》上巷，久行之，使人目明，而邪气不干，形体不垢生秽也。

Lady Yunlin says: Before sleeping at night, first close the eyes tightly and face east. As for the later instruction that one should do this at the time when *qi* is generated, this means that the initial evening rest cannot follow this practice. Only after midnight, upon waking, should one sit up to perform it. Before midday, it may be repeated and recited several times—but one must consider facing east, which does not change with the four seasons.

Press the fleshy part behind the thumbs of both hands against the eyes and wipe toward the ear openings, so that the two palms meet at the nape of the neck, repeating this twenty-seven times. Begin near the back of the palms, starting from the edge of the thumbs, first lightly pressing the eyes (as the scripture says), then wipe each eye left and right, passing over the ear openings and crossing at the back of the neck. Alternate thus, stopping only after twenty-seven repetitions.

Visualize within each eye the emanation of three colored *qi*—purple, azure, and crimson—before you. This is the internal pressing of the Three Primordial Clouds to irrigate and unite the pupils. While pressing, imagine the three colored clouds glowing luxuriantly, each rising above the face. After twenty-seven repetitions, pause briefly, then guide the three *qi* with focused intent, causing their radiance to bathe the eye pupils before repeating the practice.

Recite the following incantation:
*"Pupils of triple clouds, true lords of both eyes,
Brilliant and luminous, they infuse essence and open the pure spirit.
Grand Mystery’s cloudy forms, numinous and graceful,
Guard the paired gates and unseal the nine portals.
All joints respond in harmony, morning fluids ascend to the Mud Pill,
The body ascends to the Jade Palace, ranked among the perfected of the highest order."*
(Comprising six rhyming couplets.)

After reciting, swallow saliva fifty times, then open the eyes. This may be practiced upon sitting up and need not be confined to night—though it should be done at the time when *qi* is generated. After a year, the ears and eyes will become sharp and clear. With prolonged practice, one may see a thousand *li* afar, perceive the reflections of spirits, and hear sounds beyond ordinary hearing. This is not merely a method for brightening the eyes and opening the ears but a lofty Dao of true immortals. The immortals of Canglang Fangzhang often treasure and practice it.

This method originates from the *Scripture of the Four Luminaries of the Supreme* and is transmitted only after swearing an oath with gold and blue-green silk. Among all methods for the ears and eyes, none surpasses this one, hence the establishment of a covenant for its transmission. All practices involving cultivation, visualization, and recitation should likewise be pledged to a profound master—without such an oath, there will be no efficacy. The quantity of gold and silk is left to the practitioner’s discretion.

**Yunlin’s Instruction to Yang Shu**

On the face, one should often rub both hands until warm, following the contours closely and thoroughly. First, rub the palms together until hot, then use them to wipe the face and eyes. Afterward, smooth the hair as if combing it, and alternately massage the arms with the hands.

This visualization method may be practiced whenever there is leisure, day or night. First, rub the palms until hot, then wipe the face and eyes several times. Rub the palms together again, then wipe the face once more, repeating this four or five times. Then, pass the hands behind the neck and to the temples, alternately massaging the temples upward as if combing the hair, stopping after several dozen repetitions. Though this is a fine method for restoring youthful complexion and reversing gray hair, the character *er* (而) here is used in its standard sense.

This method comes from the *Scripture of the Elixir Landscape* and bestows a lustrous complexion, prevents wrinkles and blemishes, keeps hair from turning white, and prevents veins from protruding. After five years of practice, one’s countenance will resemble that of a young maiden—what is called "the *qi* of mountains and rivers, ever full and never depleted." This is the essence of the lower-grade *Dao of the Elixir Landscape*, which states that one should always be as full of *qi* as mountains and rivers, causing even trees and stones to flourish with vitality.

**Recorded by the Prefect**

Upon waking, there is no need to rise early—this may be done at any time after waking from sleep. First, calm the breath and regulate the *qi*, making inhalations and exhalations slow and subtle. Sit upright, facing the direction of the moon’s current palace. Clasp the hands together, then reverse the clasp and extend the arms fully forward. Bring them up to cover the back of the neck, then tilt the head back to look upward, raising the neck and lifting both hands, straining against them three or four times.

*(The character *xing* (兴) means "to rise"; here, it refers to clasping the hands to cover the back of the neck, then tilting the head back to raise the neck, exerting force as if struggling, then lowering it gently. Repeat this three or four times, and one may hear the neck bones crack. The character *xing* may also be written as *yu* (与).)*

Afterward, move and bend the body: unclasp the hands, lower the head, bend at the waist, and rotate the back, with the feet possibly lifting and resting. Stretch the hands to the four extremes: raise both hands above the head, then extend them forcefully to the sides, bringing them forward before stretching them fully backward, reversing the stretch. For the reverse stretch and side pulls, first arch the waist backward, then bring the hands together to follow the body, swaying left and right and pulling to the sides. To "proclaim and shake the hundred joints," continue moving vigorously, ensuring that the limbs, feet, hands, arms, and knees all circulate fully. Perform each movement three times, repeating the entire sequence three times—this does not mean completing all movements before starting over.

This is a matter of oral instruction: the movements of the four limbs cannot all be recorded in writing, so the oral instructions must detail their forms and applications. The intent is simply to follow the annotations provided.

**From the *Essential Scripture of the Great Cavern: Massage Section of the Elixir Landscape***
This practice harmonizes essence and blood, prevents the intrusion of wind-*qi*, and if practiced long enough, confers immunity to death and illness. This is an example from the *Great Cavern*—the scroll titles are numerous and not limited to the thirty-nine chapters. Later references to the *Upper Scroll of the Elixir Landscape of the Great Cavern* and the *Great Cavern’s Grand Exorcism Incantation* show that there are many such texts.

**Recorded by the Prefect**

Upon waking, first use a handkerchief or thick cloth to wipe the neck on all sides and behind the ears, ensuring thorough coverage until warm. Then, smooth the hair and massage the neck as if combing it countless times. After a long while, massage both hands and treat the face and eyes. When finished, swallow saliva thirty times to guide the internal fluids.

*(This means that upon first waking, one should face the moon’s palace and perform this method before proceeding to the clasped-hand and reverse-stretch practices.)*

**From the *Upper Chapter of the Essential Scripture of the Elixir Landscape of the Great Cavern***
With prolonged practice, this method sharpens the eyes, prevents the intrusion of evil *qi*, and keeps the body free from filth and grime.

chunks.original_text: 字，女忌反。 长史书。 若体中不宁，此谓觉有不佳处，而无的所苦者。 当反舌塞喉，漱津咽液无数，极力卷舌上向，屈以塞喉而漱咽也。 须臾不宁之痾即自除也，当时亦当觉体中宽软也。 亦可兼行此中诸按摩存祝之法。 右出消摩上灵叙中。 消摩品号，亦如大洞卷目，例皆不少也。 长史书。 右前来至此几四事，不显何真所告。 耳欲得数按抑其左右，亦令无数，令人聪彻，所谓营治城郭，名书皇籍。 一真本云营治城郭，其义亦不相乖，两耳为一面之界域，故宜治理之也。 鼻亦欲按其左右唯令数，令人气平，所谓灌溉中岳，名书帝录。 鼻为面之岳山，内景所谓之天中之岳。 精谨修鼻，孔中毛亦欲数灭除，恒使洁利。 此二事皆可以闲时为，用手按抑，上下摩治无数，则城郭坚完，山岳峙秀，皇籍帝录，可得而书耳。 右此二法，方丈台照灵李夫人出用，云消摩经上篇法。 此照字当为昭，书之误耳。 长史书。 常能以手掩口息，临目微气，久时手中生液，通以摩拭面目，常行之，使人体香。 以两手竖掩鼻口，令呼吸通於手下，须有液，仍以摩拭，竟又掩，无定限数，亦使人光泽。 云出石景赤字经。 常欲以手按目及鼻之两眦，闭气为之，气通辄止，吐而复始，恒行之，眼乃洞观。 此用两手各第三指侠鼻，按目下内眦，无正限数，通气小举指，更闭又按，亦可三九过也。 云出太上天关三经。 按下品目有天关三图经，疑阙图字也。 常欲闭目而卧，安身微气，使如卧状，令傍人不觉也，此昼夜无定，非止欲卧时，当平枕椻向，使气调静也。 乃内视远听四方，令我耳目注百万里之卧，久行之，亦自见万里之卧事，精心为之，乃见万里卧事也。 后云当先起一方，如此方方各存，都讫，更通存四方皆如闻见也。 耳目初注东方，令见山川城郭，闻诸玄响，并依稀作像，觉我耳目视听遥掷远处，恍然忘形乃佳，亦应先从一里十里百里千里，渐渐以去也。 又耳中亦恒闻金玉丝竹之音，此妙法也。 初亦存闻之，后乃得实闻也。 四方者，总其言耳，当先起一方，而内注视听，初为之，实无仿髴，久久诚自入妙。 夫修道存思，事皆如此，岁月不积，诚思不深，理未知觉，不得以未即感验，便致废弃，钻石拜山，可谓有志。 云出紫度炎光经内视中方。 坐常欲闭目内视，存见五藏肠胃，久久行之，自得分明了了也。 存见时应想其形色次第，高下大小，状如自说，其藏府名序，并注二十四神中，不复两纪。 云出丹字紫书三五顺行经。 临食上勿道死事，勿露食物，来众邪气。 食时欲常向本命及王气，凡食玲暖，皆不可不覆，鬼邪喜先来歆响，则余味便为浊秽，亦能致病也。 数沐浴，每至甲子当沐，不尔当几月旦，使人通灵。 几月即奇月也，谓正月三月五月七月九月十一月也，月中有甲子，便可重沐。 消尸用四时王日，仙忌用十一月十一日，九真又用三月三日，五月五日，皆应沐也，月得一过两过乃佳。 浴不患数，患人不能耳，荡炼尸臭，而真气来入。 紫阳真人告曰：可数沐浴，濯水疾之气，消积考之瑕，亦致真之阶。 紫微夫人曰：沐浴不数，魄之性也，违魄返是，炼其浊秽，魄自亡矣，知此沐浴便甚须数也，此事自为易矣，於冬月汤少为难瞻尔。
chunks.translated_text:
**Recorded by the Prefect**

The character ** is pronounced as *nì*, with the initial of *女* and the final of *忌*.

If the body feels unwell—meaning one senses discomfort without a specific ailment—press the tongue against the throat, rinse with saliva, and swallow repeatedly. Forcefully curl the tongue upward to block the throat while rinsing and swallowing. Soon, the discomfort will dissipate, and the body will feel relaxed and supple. This method may also be combined with the various massage and visualization practices described herein.

**From the *Upper Scroll of the Scripture of Dissolving and Rubbing the Numinous Sequence***

The *Dissolving and Rubbing* section, like the chapters of the *Great Cavern*, is by no means insignificant.

**Recorded by the Prefect**

The four preceding methods do not specify which Perfected One transmitted them.

Frequently press and rub the ears on both sides without count, sharpening one’s hearing. This is called "tending the city walls" and is recorded in the *Imperial Register*. An alternate version reads "tending the city walls," with no discrepancy in meaning. Since the ears mark the boundaries of the face, they must be properly tended.

Frequently press the sides of the nose to regulate the breath, ensuring evenness. This is called "irrigating the Central Peak" and is recorded in the *Emperor’s Record*. The nose is the mountain peak of the face, the "Central Peak within the Inner Landscape."

Diligently tend to the nose, and regularly remove hairs from the nostrils to keep them clean and unobstructed. Both practices may be performed at leisure: use the hands to press, rub, and tend the ears and nose without count. Thus, the city walls will stand firm, the mountain peaks will tower in splendor, and the *Imperial Register* and *Emperor’s Record* may be inscribed.

**These two methods were transmitted by Lady Li of the Terrace of Illuminating Numinosity, as recorded in the *Upper Scroll of the Scripture of Dissolving and Rubbing***. The character *照* should be *昭*, an error in transcription.

**Recorded by the Prefect**

Regularly cover the mouth with the hand while breathing gently with eyes closed. Over time, saliva will accumulate in the palm; use it to massage and wipe the face. Consistent practice imparts fragrance to the body.

Place both hands upright over the nose and mouth, allowing breath to pass beneath them. When saliva forms, use it to massage and wipe, then cover again. There is no fixed number of repetitions, but this practice enhances one’s radiance.

**From the *Scripture of the Red Character Stone Landscape***

Frequently press the corners of the eyes and the sides of the nose while holding the breath. When the breath flows smoothly, stop; exhale and begin anew. With persistent practice, the eyes will gain penetrating vision. Use the third finger of each hand to press the inner corners of the eyes beside the nose. There is no fixed number of repetitions; when the breath flows, slightly lift the fingers, then close and press again. This may also be done twenty-seven times.

**From the *Three Scriptures of the Celestial Pass of the Supreme***

The *Lower Scroll* mentions the *Three Illustrated Scriptures of the Celestial Pass*; the character *图* may be missing.

Regularly lie down with eyes closed, relax the body, and breathe gently to appear as if asleep, so others remain unaware. This may be practiced at any time, day or night, not only when resting. The head should rest evenly on the pillow, aligning the breath and calming the *qi*.

Inwardly gaze and listen to the four directions, extending one’s ears and eyes to a hundred thousand *li*. With prolonged practice, one will naturally perceive events at a distance of ten thousand *li*. Focus the mind intently, and the visions will become clear.

Begin by focusing on one direction. For example, direct the ears and eyes eastward to see mountains, rivers, and city walls, and hear mysterious sounds, forming indistinct yet vivid impressions. Feel as though one’s senses extend far into the distance, forgetting the body’s form—this is ideal. One may start with one *li*, then ten, a hundred, or a thousand, gradually expanding the range.

One may also constantly hear the sounds of gold, jade, silk, and bamboo within the ears. This is a sublime method. Initially, one visualizes hearing them; later, the sounds become real.

The "four directions" are mentioned collectively, but one should begin with a single direction, inwardly directing sight and hearing. At first, there may be no clear impressions, but with time and sincerity, one will naturally attain mastery. All Daoist visualization practices follow this principle. Without accumulating months and years of practice or deep sincerity, one will not perceive the underlying patterns. Do not abandon the practice simply because immediate results are not felt. Those who drill through stone or bow before mountains may be said to possess true resolve.

**From the *Inner Visualization of the Central Directions in the Scripture of Purple Radiance and Blazing Light***

When sitting, regularly close the eyes and inwardly visualize the five viscera and intestines. With prolonged practice, their forms and colors will become distinctly clear. During visualization, imagine their shapes, colors, order, relative positions, and sizes as if describing them. The names and sequences of the organs are recorded in the *Twenty-Four Spirits*; they will not be repeated here.

**From the *Scripture of the Three and Five in Harmony with the Purple Writ of the Cinnabar Character***

When eating, do not speak of death or expose food, lest various evil *qi* gather. While eating, always face the direction of one’s life destiny and the *wang qi*. All food, whether hot or cold, should be covered. Ghosts and evil spirits delight in approaching to partake of the aroma, turning the remaining flavors turbid and foul, which can also cause illness.

Bathe frequently. On *jiazi* days, one should bathe; if not, then on the first day of each month. This practice enhances spiritual clarity. The "odd months" refer to the first, third, fifth, seventh, ninth, and eleventh months. If a *jiazi* day falls within these months, one may bathe again.

To dispel corpse *qi*, use the royal days of the four seasons. For immortals’ taboos, use the eleventh day of the eleventh month. The Nine Perfected also use the third day of the third month and the fifth day of the fifth month—all suitable for bathing. Bathing once or twice a month is ideal. The concern is not frequency but the practitioner’s diligence. Washing away the stench of the corpse allows true *qi* to enter.

The Perfected One of Purple Yang stated: "Bathe frequently to wash away the *qi* of illness and eliminate the blemishes of accumulated decay. This is also the path to attaining the true."

Lady of the Purple Tenuity said: "Infrequent bathing is the nature of the *po*. To oppose the *po* and return to correctness, refine away its turbidity and filth, and the *po* will naturally vanish. Knowing this, one should bathe frequently. This practice is simple, though using warm water in winter may be slightly challenging."

chunks.original_text: 洗澡时常存六丁，令人所向如愿。 谓旦夕经常澡洗也，至沐浴时亦可存向之耳。 六丁即六丁神女，此神善与人感通，易为存召，亦应向六丁所在，谓甲子旬即向卯也。 其玉女别有名字服色，在灵飞中。 理发向王，谓月建之方面也，栉发梳头沐发皆尔，按仙忌忌北向理发，今十一月既建，子宜当犹向亥，此正北不可犯也。 既栉之初，谓初就栉之始，行祝行栉。 而微祝曰： 泥丸玄华，保精长存，左为隐月，右为日根，六合清炼，百神受恩。 祝毕咽液三过。 此祝中云左月右日者，是阴阳互相入即紫文三魂飞精之义，故有隐根之目也，玄华是发神之名，六合为鬓下之府，凡诸祝辞皆有旨训，非但此文而已。 右八条玄师南岳夫人所勑使施用，长史书。 理发欲向王地，既栉发之始，前无发字，又以始为初。 而微祝曰： 泥丸玄华，保精长存，左为隐月，右为日根，六合清炼，百神受恩。 祝毕咽液三过。 按南岳夫人已受此法，今安妃又告，当是前后不相知而用法犹皆同。 能常行之，发不落而日生，当数易栉，栉之取多而不使痛。 意言数栉者，谓数易栉处，而紫微又云更番用之，此便是用一栉恐热，损头伤发故耳。 今当四五枚更互用使冷也。 亦可令侍者栉取多也。 上学之士衣服将席尚不使人近，何容以头与人栉之，正可自为。 於是血液不滞，发根常坚。 右按九华所告，令施用，云出太极绿经。 长史书。 《真诰》云：栉头理发，欲得多过，通流血气，散风湿也，数易栉更番用之也，亦可不须解发也。 栉发之事，频三真言之，此为宜行之急，且欲勤勤告仙侯，令为返白之道也。 右紫微夫人言。 长史书。
chunks.translated_text:
When bathing, frequently invoke the Six Dings, and all your aspirations will be fulfilled as desired. This means maintaining regular washing day and night, and even during the act of bathing, one may invoke them. The Six Dings are the Six Ding Spirit Maidens, deities readily responsive to human communion and easily summoned. One should also face the direction where the Six Dings reside—during the *jiazi* cycle, this is the *mao* direction. Each of these Jade Maidens has distinct names and attire, as recorded in the *Lingfei*.

When combing hair, face the direction of the monthly *wang* (ruling position). This applies to all acts of grooming, washing, or combing the hair. According to the immortals’ taboos, one must never comb hair facing north. In the eleventh month, when *zi* is established, one should still face *hai*; the due north is strictly forbidden. At the very beginning of combing, when the comb first touches the hair, recite the following incantation while combing:

*"Mud-pellet’s mysterious blossom, preserve essence and endure,
Left, the hidden moon; right, the sun’s root.
The Six Harmonies refine and purify,
A hundred spirits receive grace."*

After reciting, swallow saliva three times.

The phrase "left moon, right sun" signifies the mutual interpenetration of yin and yang, embodying the principle of the Three Hun’s flying essence in purple script. Thus, they are called the "hidden root." *Xuanhua* is the name of the hair spirit, and the *Six Harmonies* refer to the residence beneath the temples. All incantations carry profound meaning, not merely this passage alone.

The above eight clauses were commanded by the Mystic Master, the Lady of South Marchmount, for implementation. Recorded by the Prefect.

When combing hair, face the direction of the *wang* position. At the very start of combing—here, "start" replaces "beginning"—recite the incantation:

*"Mud-pellet’s mysterious blossom, preserve essence and endure,
Left, the hidden moon; right, the sun’s root.
The Six Harmonies refine and purify,
A hundred spirits receive grace."*

After reciting, swallow saliva three times.

The Lady of South Marchmount had already received this method, and now Lady An has also transmitted it. This suggests that though they were unaware of each other’s teachings, the method remains identical. Practicing this regularly will prevent hair loss and promote daily growth. One should frequently change combs, using many teeth without causing pain. The phrase "frequently comb" means to alternate the areas being combed. The Lady of Purple Tenuity also advised using combs in rotation, as using a single comb may generate heat, harming the scalp and hair. Thus, one should alternate among four or five combs to keep them cool. Alternatively, one may have an attendant comb the hair thoroughly.

Scholars of the Dao do not allow others near their clothing or mats; how much less should they permit others to comb their hair? This should be done personally. Thus, blood and fluids will flow unimpeded, and hair roots will remain firm.

The above, recorded by the Prefect, is based on the instructions from Jiuhua for implementation, said to originate from the *Tai Ji Lü Jing*.

The *Zhen Gao* states: When combing or grooming hair, do so frequently to circulate blood and qi, dispersing wind and dampness. Alternate combs in rotation, and there is no need to loosen the hair. The matter of combing hair has been emphasized by the Three Perfected Ones, for it is an urgent practice to be observed. I earnestly urge Immortal Marquis to follow this path to restore black hair.

Recorded by the Prefect, as spoken by the Lady of Purple Tenuity.

chunks.original_text: 若履掩秽及诸不洁处，当洗浴解形以除之。 其法用竹叶十两，凡诸竹叶皆可用耳，北机之上精，不显其品族也。 桃皮削取白皮四两，乾者亦可用，此桃皮是其子可食者，生山中者亦好，非山桃也。 二物并用古秤，乾桃皮则半之。 以清水一斛二斗，於釜中煮之，令一沸，一沸而已，不事於浓也。 出适寒温，以浴形，即万殗消除也。 既以除殗，又辟湿痹疮痒之疾，且竹虚素而内白，桃即却邪而折秽，故用此二物，以消形中之滓浊也。 竹质既虚，内又素诤，桃主却秽，二气相须而成也。 《礼》：君临臣丧，使巫祝先以桃茢拂除。 此亦以去其恶气也。 天人下游既返，未曾不用此水以自荡也。 寻真人降世，其质便不能不染乎秽气，所用桃竹时，当是诸名山有宫室处以洗浴也。 此语亦或是厉人耳，果其如此，神仙亦何甚异於人乎，唯能凌虚不死而已。 至於世间符水祝漱，外舍之近术，皆莫比於此方也。 世中旧有解殗之法，比此亦犹培喽之与方壶矣。 若浴者益佳，但不用此水以沐耳，炼尸之素浆，正宜以浴耳，真奇秘也。 沐者既以浴竟，复宜依常法沐头，非用此水以沐也，若沐竟，以此水少少洗刷，亦当无嫌。 此水一名练尸素浆，止供澡浴耳。 解殗之事，学者之所急，此之秘方，千金非宝也。 右紫微王夫人所勑用，云出太上九变十化易新经。 长史书。 服仙药常向本命，服毕勿道死丧凶事，犯胎伤神，徒服无益。 凡服仙世方药，皆当如此，唯初神丸及金丹，云东向耳。 右东卿告杨君，长史书两本。 君曰：常以夜半时，去枕平卧，握固放体，气调而微者，身神具矣。 如有不具，便速起烧香，平坐闭目，握固两膝上，心存体神，使两目中有白气，如鸡子大，在目前，则复故也，五日一行之。 按此法是存二十四神之后，令所说唯云存神而不言其本，当是述彼事耳。 目中白气即是明镜之道，但五日一行，止是镜事，非前具神如此，或当参以为用也，今既修大经亦可略此。 君曰：式规之法，使人目明，久而彻视，二十四神谓之拂童之道，使彻见二十四神之法。 常以甲子之旬，经用庚午之日，日中之时，取东流清水合真丹，经用水一斗，真珠二铢，向月建左行，搅之二七过。 以洗目，日向清明东旦二七过。 经云万向东二七过洗目。 常行之佳。 此亦粗说经事耳，已行本法，不复用此。 凡经方术数所行所用，多有不验，事皆如斯，此之疏略，岂与本经相似，今若不见彼法，则应施用此道，所以白首无成者，皆由兹辈也。 君曰：欲为道，目想日月，目中常见日月之形，亦兼存左目为日，右目为月也。 耳响师声，耳中常闻师之音响，亦兼言语声气取类於师也。 口恒吐死取生气，随四时衰王吐死吸生，假令春则吐黄而吸青也。 体象五星，谓如裴君所存，五星在左右前后头上也。 行常如跚空，行步若在云虚之中，非如履斗乘纲也。 心存思长生，坐卧行来，常念神仙。 慎笑节语，无事於笑，何须多言。 常思其形，常自识其面貌形色也。 要道也。 此诸道虽无正术可修，而并是向学之源本矣。 右二条云裴君言。 长史、掾两书本。 右前至此几三十七事，并朝拜摄养，施用起居之道。 每当经危险之路，鬼庙之间，意中诸有疑难之处，心将有微忌，勑所经履者，乃当先反舌内向，反舌内向柱喉中，临祝乃伸之。
chunks.translated_text:
If one treads upon filth or any unclean place, one should bathe to purify the body and dispel it. The method uses ten liang of bamboo leaves—any bamboo leaves may be used, for the essence of those from the northern loom is not distinguished by species. Take four liang of white inner bark from the peach tree (dried may also be used); this refers to the bark of the edible peach, including those growing wild in the mountains, not the mountain peach. Both ingredients are measured by the ancient scale, with dried peach bark halved in quantity. Boil them in one *hu* and two *dou* of clear water in a cauldron, allowing it to come to a single boil—just once, without seeking thickness. Remove and adjust to a suitable temperature to bathe the body, and all impurities will be dissolved. This not only removes filth but also wards off damp impediment, sores, and itching. Moreover, bamboo is hollow and pure within, while peach repels evil and dispels foulness; thus, these two substances are used to purge the body’s turbidity. Bamboo’s nature is hollow and its interior pristine, while peach governs the expulsion of filth—these two *qi* complement each other. As the *Rites* states: When a lord attends a minister’s funeral, the shaman-priest first sweeps away evil with a peach-wood broom. This, too, is to dispel malign *qi*. When celestial beings descend and return, they never fail to cleanse themselves with this water. When perfected ones descend to the world, their forms cannot but be tainted by foul *qi*; thus, peach and bamboo are used in the baths of the palaces on famous mountains. This may sound harsh, but if true, how greatly do immortals differ from mortals? Only in their ability to ascend the void and escape death. As for the talismanic waters and incantations of the mundane world—mere external arts of the outer schools—none compare to this formula. There are old methods for dispelling filth, but beside this, they are like a mound beside Mount Fanghu. If one bathes, it is even better, though this water should not be used for washing the hair. The refined corpse’s pure essence is precisely for bathing—truly a wondrous secret. After bathing, one should wash the hair as usual, not with this water. If, after washing the hair, one rinses it slightly with this water, there is no harm. This water is also called the *Refined Corpse’s Pure Essence*, meant solely for bathing. Dispelling filth is urgent for the student; this secret formula is beyond price.

The above was commanded for use by Lady Wang of Purple Tenuity, said to originate from the *Tai Shang Jiu Bian Shi Hua Yi Xin Jing*. Recorded by the Prefect.

When ingesting immortal medicines, always face the direction of one’s life destiny. After ingestion, do not speak of death, mourning, or inauspicious matters, lest one harm the spirit and waste the medicine’s benefit. All immortal elixirs and worldly formulas should be taken thus, except for the *Initial Spirit Pill* and *Golden Elixir*, which are taken facing east.

The above was told to Master Yang by the Eastern Minister. Recorded by the Prefect in two versions.

Master said: At midnight, remove the pillow and lie flat, clench the fists, relax the body, and regulate the breath until it is subtle—then the body’s spirits are complete. If any are lacking, rise quickly, burn incense, sit upright with eyes closed, clench the fists over the knees, and visualize the body’s spirits. Envision a white *qi* the size of a chicken’s egg before the eyes, and the spirits will be restored. Practice this once every five days. This method follows the visualization of the twenty-four spirits, though here it speaks only of visualizing the spirits without mentioning their origin—likely a summary of that practice. The white *qi* in the eyes pertains to the *Way of the Bright Mirror*, but practicing it every five days is merely the mirror’s work, not the full restoration of the spirits. Perhaps it may be integrated for use, but if one is cultivating the great scriptures, this may be omitted.

Master said: The method of *shi gui* sharpens the eyes and, with time, grants penetrating vision. The twenty-four spirits are called the *Way of the Wiping Youth*, enabling one to clearly see the twenty-four spirits. On the *gengwu* day within the *jiazi* ten-day period, at noon, take clear east-flowing water and mix it with true cinnabar. Use one *dou* of water and two *zhu* of true pearl, stirring twenty-one times toward the moon’s position. Wash the eyes with this, facing east at dawn, twenty-one times. The scripture says: Always face east and wash the eyes twenty-one times. Regular practice is excellent. This is but a rough summary of the scriptural method; if one has already practiced the original method, this is no longer needed. Most scriptural formulas and techniques prove ineffective, as is often the case. Such brevity—how could it compare to the original scripture? If one has not seen the original method, this may be employed. Thus, those who toil in vain into old age do so because of such incomplete teachings.

Master said: To cultivate the Way, visualize the sun and moon in the eyes, always seeing their forms. Also visualize the left eye as the sun and the right as the moon. Listen for the master’s voice in the ears, always hearing the master’s sound, including speech and breath, taking them as models. The mouth constantly exhales the dead and inhales the living *qi*, adjusting to the four seasons’ waxing and waning. For example, in spring, exhale yellow and inhale green. Embody the five stars, as in Master Pei’s visualization, with the five stars positioned to the left, right, front, back, and above the head. Walk as if treading empty space, moving as though in the void, not as if pacing the Dipper or riding the net. The mind constantly contemplates long life; in sitting, lying, walking, and coming, always think of immortality. Be cautious in laughter and measured in speech—why speak much when unnecessary? Constantly reflect on one’s form, always recognizing one’s own appearance and complexion. These are essential practices. Though these methods lack formal techniques for cultivation, they are the wellsprings of learning.

The above two passages are said to be Master Pei’s words. Recorded by the Prefect and his assistant in two versions.

From the beginning to this point, there are thirty-seven matters concerning court rituals, nurturing life, and daily practices. Whenever traversing dangerous paths, passing through ghostly temples, or encountering places of doubt or subtle taboo, one should first curl the tongue inward to press against the throat. Only after reciting the incantation should the tongue be extended.

chunks.original_text: 咽液三过，毕，以左手第二、第三指捻两鼻孔下人中之本，鼻中隔孔之内际也，三十六过，即手急按，勿举指计数也。 此急按，於急按中阴数，以一息为一过之久。 鼻中隔孔之际名曰山源，一名鬼井，一名神池，一名邪根，一名魂台也。 此后祝中有此五名，故先显其目，紫微夫人云：山源是鼻下人中之本侧，在鼻下小入谷中也。 用针针之，亦治卒死。 捻毕，因叩齿七通，毕又进手心以掩鼻，捻毕未去手，仍叩齿，叩齿竟，仍进手掌以掩鼻口，指端至发际，拜覆明堂上。 於是临目，临目内存明堂三君，以铃镜赤光焕而掷之，又存泥丸赤子帝君，执诵大洞真经以威摄之。 乃微祝曰： 朱乌凌天，神威内张，山源四镇，鬼井逃亡，神池吐气，邪根伏藏，魂台四明，琼房玲琅，玉真巍峨，坐镇明堂，手挥紫霞，头建晨光，执咏洞经，三十九章，中有辟邪龙虎，截岳斩冈，猛兽奔牛，衔刀吞镶，揭山钟天，神雀毒龙，六领吐火，啖鬼之王，电堵雷父，制星流横，枭磕驳灼，逆风横行，天兽罗陈，皆在我傍，吐火万丈，以除不祥，群精启道，封落山乡，千神百灵，并首稽颡，泽尉捧炉，为我烧香，所在所经，万神奉迎。 毕，又叩齿三通，乃开目，除去左手，於是感激灵根，天狩来卫，千精震伏，莫干我气。 此祝中并是神兽灵司之名号，故可震却邪精也。 右出大洞真经高上内章，遏邪大祝上法。 长史书。 北帝杀鬼之法，先叩齿三十六下，乃咒曰： 天蓬天蓬，九元杀童，五丁都司，高刀北公，七政八灵，太上浩凶，长颅巨兽，手把帝锺，素枭三神，严驾夔龙，威剑神王，斩邪灭踪，紫气乘天，丹霞赫冲，吞魔食鬼，横身饮风，苍舌绿齿，四目老翁，天丁力士，威南御凶，天驺激戾，威北衔锋，三十万兵，卫我九重，辟尸千里，祛却不祥，敢有小鬼，欲来见状，链天大斧，斩鬼五形，炎帝裂血，北斗然骨，四明破骸，天猷灭类，神刀一下，万鬼自溃。 毕，四言一啄齿以为节也。 凡三十六句，则三＋六啄齿。
chunks.translated_text:
Swallow the saliva three times, then with the second and third fingers of the left hand, pinch the base of the philtrum beneath the nostrils—where the inner edge of the nasal septum lies—thirty-six times. Press firmly without lifting the fingers to count. This firm pressing is done while silently counting, with each breath marking one cycle.

The region between the nasal septum and the nostrils is called the *Mountain Source*, also known as the *Ghost Well*, the *Divine Pool*, the *Root of Evil*, or the *Terrace of the Hun*. As these five names appear in the later incantation, they are first clarified here. The Lady of Purple Tenuity states: "The *Mountain Source* lies at the base of the philtrum beneath the nose, slightly recessed within the valley." If needled with a pin, it can also treat sudden death.

After pinching, knock the teeth seven times. Then advance the palm to cover the nose, and without removing the hand, knock the teeth again. Once done, further advance the palm to cover both nose and mouth, with the fingertips reaching the hairline, bowing to cover the *Bright Hall*. At this moment, close the eyes and inwardly visualize the Three Lords of the *Bright Hall*, casting forth the radiant red light of the bell-mirror. Also visualize the Infant Lord of the *Mud-Pill Palace*, reciting the *True Scripture of the Great Cavern* to exert awe and command.

Then softly intone the incantation:
*"Crimson Crow soars heavenward, divine might unfurls within.
The Four Pillars of Mountain Source, the Ghost Well flees in flight.
The Divine Pool exhales its breath, the Root of Evil cowers low.
The Terrace of the Hun shines forth, the Jade Chamber rings with light.
The Jade Perfected stands sublime, enthroned within the Bright Hall,
Wielding purple mist in hand, crowned with the dawn’s first glow.
Reciting the Cavern Scripture, its thirty-nine chapters hold
Dragons and tigers that repel evil, cleaving peaks and rending hills,
Fierce beasts and charging oxen, blades devoured and spears consumed,
Uplifting mountains, tolling heaven, poisonous dragons and divine birds,
Six-headed beasts that breathe forth fire, devourers of demon kings,
Lightning-walled and thunder-sired, restraining stars in wild array,
Owls and blazing creatures, traversing winds in bold defiance,
Celestial beasts in ordered ranks, all stand beside me now,
Spewing flames a thousand yards to banish every ill.
A host of spirits clear the path, sealing off mountain realms,
A thousand gods and hundred spirits bow their heads in reverence,
Marshals bearing censers burn incense on my behalf.
Wherever I tread, wherever I pass, ten thousand spirits come to greet."*

When finished, knock the teeth three more times, then open the eyes and remove the left hand. Thus, the numinous root is stirred, celestial huntsmen arrive to guard, a thousand spirits tremble and submit, none daring to disturb my qi.

These names within the incantation are all titles of divine beasts and spirit officers, hence their power to repel malevolent forces.

The above is drawn from the *Highest Inner Chapters of the True Scripture of the Great Cavern*, the supreme method of the *Great Incantation for Suppressing Evil*. Recorded by the Prefect.

The method of the *Northern Emperor for Slaying Ghosts* begins by knocking the teeth thirty-six times, then reciting the incantation:
*"Heavenly Peng, Heavenly Peng,
Nine Primes slay the youth,
Five Ding Commanders,
Lofty Blade of the Northern Duke,
Seven Governors, Eight Spirits,
Supreme One subdues the fierce,
Long-skulled giant beast,
Grasping the Emperor’s Bell,
Three White Owls, divine spirits,
Driving the leviathan’s chariot,
Mighty Sword Spirit King,
Severing evil, erasing traces,
Purple qi ascends heaven,
Crimson radiance blazes forth,
Devouring demons, consuming ghosts,
Body transverse, drinking wind,
Azure tongue, green teeth,
Four-eyed ancient elder,
Heavenly Ding warriors,
Awe to the south, repelling evil,
Celestial couriers, fierce and swift,
Awe to the north, bearing blades,
Three hundred thousand soldiers,
Guard my ninefold layers,
Expelling corpses a thousand miles,
Dispelling all misfortune.
Dare any petty ghost
Approach to witness this?
Chains of heaven, mighty axes,
Severing the five forms of ghosts,
Flame Emperor rends their flesh,
Northern Dipper burns their bones,
Four Luminaries shatter their frames,
Heavenly Strategy annihilates their kind.
One stroke of the divine blade—
Ten thousand ghosts scatter in rout."*

Each four-character line is punctuated by a single tap of the teeth. For all thirty-six lines, there are thirty-six taps.

The above two passages are said to be Master Pei’s words. Recorded by the Prefect and his assistant in two versions.

From the beginning to this point, there are thirty-seven matters concerning court rituals, nurturing life, and daily practices. Whenever traversing dangerous paths, passing through ghostly temples, or encountering places of doubt or subtle taboo, one should first curl the tongue inward to press against the throat. Only after reciting the incantation should the tongue be extended.

chunks.original_text: 若冥夜白日得祝，为恒祝也，此无正时节修事，有闲及晓夜之际，诸疑暗之处，便可祝之。 当微言。 鬼有三被此祝者，眼睛盲烂，而身即死。 此谓诸杀鬼邪鬼，及天地间自有恶强鬼辈，闻此而死耳，非人死之魂爽为鬼者也，如是鬼眼亦是有睛，故盲烂则便死矣。 此上神祝，斩鬼之司名，咒中有酆都中官位，及诸神名字，故鬼闻而怖死也。 许某领威南兵千人，即此却凶者也，炎帝即亥帝，四明即诸公矣。 北帝秘其道，北帝应遣鬼神人，而值此祝，使不可复得，故秘其法也。 若世人得此世祝，能行之，便不死之道也。 人之死也，皆为诸鬼神所杀耳，今既不可取，便为不复死也。 男女大小，皆可仔之，但患其不知此咒耳，知者密用，则无限於小大。 此语似是令告长史之家也。 困病行此立愈。 鬼既奔走，病岂不除。 叩齿当临目存见五藏，具五神，自然存也。 谓初叩峦二十六时，应临目内视，存具五藏，以次想之，皆令分明，五藏之神备在於内，然后可得乘正以制邪御神，次诛鬼耳。 酆都中秘此祝法，今密及之，不可泄非有道者，其共秘之乎。 此虽非高真之至典，而是剪鬼之上术，凶恶既消，则正气可按，且以诛邪边试，学者之要法也。 而诸人多轻其浅小，每致传世，使神咒隐验，呵执不行，殊为可责。 右杨君、掾书两本。 罗酆山在北方癸地，其上下并有鬼神宫室，山上有六宫，洞中有六宫，亦同名相像如一。 第一宫名为纣绝阴天宫，以次东行，第二宫名为太杀谅事宗天宫，第三宫名为明晨耐犯武城天宫，第四宫名为恬照罪气天宫，第五宫名为宗灵七非天宫，第六宫名为敢司连宛屡天宫。 此六宫内外同名，第一最在西，次东列并南向，一宫辄周回千里，悉鬼神之府也。 世人有知酆都六天宫门名，则百鬼不敢为害。 前云石是宫名，而此及咒并云是门名者，则门取宫以为名，故同一号耳。 鬼辈闻人知此名，则言是天宫之主领者，故不敢犯害。 欲卧时，先向北祝之三过，微其音也。 亦当少斜向癸地，通作一遍祝，竟辄六过啄齿，乃重祝，凡三过止也。 祝曰： 吾是太上弟子，下统六天，六天之宫，是吾所部，不但所部，乃太上之所主。 吾知六天之宫名，是故长生，敢有犯者，太上斩汝形。 第一宫名纣绝阴天宫，以次东行，第二宫名#1。 一遍百一十九字。 从此以次，讫六宫止。 即以次呼前所书宫名也。 乃啄齿六下，乃卧。 三过竟，乃更为余事，此便卧者，止是行一法耳。 辟诸鬼邪之气，夕中先祝石笋文，乃读此项梁城作酆宫颂曰： 纣绝标帝晨，谅事构重阿。 炎如霄中姻，勃若景曜华。 武阳带神锋，恬照吞清河。 阊阖临丹井，云门郁嵯峨。 七非通奇盖，连宛亦敷魔。 六天横北道，此是鬼神家。 其颂有二万言，今略道六天之宫名钞出之耳，夜中亦可微读之，亦云辟鬼。 此既有宫门之名，故鬼亦畏之。 按前第三宫名武城，今颂云武阳者，此或当两名，及别有义耳，似非误也。 右二条中君告。 杨君、掾两书本。
chunks.translated_text:
If one recites this incantation by day or night, it becomes a perpetual invocation. There is no fixed time for its practice; whenever one has leisure or at the junctures of dawn and dusk, in any place of doubt or darkness, one may recite it—whispering the words.

When ghosts hear this incantation thrice, their eyes rot and blind, and their bodies perish at once. This refers to all slaying ghosts and malevolent spirits, as well as the inherently wicked and powerful ghosts that roam between heaven and earth. Upon hearing this, they die—not the lingering souls of the dead who become ghosts. Such ghosts do possess eyes, and thus their blindness and decay bring immediate death.

This divine incantation bears the authority of the Office of Ghost-Slaying. Within its words lie the titles of the officials of Fengdu and the names of the gods, so that ghosts hear it and die in terror. The "thousand warriors led by Xu, wielding the might of the southern forces" are those who repel evil. The Flame Emperor is the Emperor of Hai, and the Four Luminaries are the Lords of the Four Directions. The Northern Emperor guards this Way in secrecy, for he commands the spirits and men who dispel ghosts. If one encounters this incantation, the ghosts can no longer prevail, hence its secrecy.

Should one in this world obtain and practice this incantation, it becomes the Way to avoid death. All human death is caused by the slaying of ghosts and spirits; once they can no longer claim a life, one ceases to die. Men and women, young and old, may all practice it—only hindered by ignorance of the spell. Those who know it must use it in secret, for its power knows no bounds of age or stature.

These words seem intended for the household of a chief administrator. When afflicted by illness, reciting this brings instant recovery. If ghosts flee, how can sickness remain? When tapping the teeth, one should close the eyes and visualize the five viscera, each inhabited by its respective spirit—this arises naturally.

At the first tap of the teeth, twenty-six times, one should close the eyes and inwardly behold the five viscera in sequence, imagining each clearly. The spirits of the five viscera reside within; only then can one align with the true and subdue the perverse, commanding the spirits and executing ghosts.

The secrets of this incantation are held within Fengdu. Now they are discreetly shared—let them not be revealed to the unworthy, but guarded by those of the Dao. Though this is not the highest scripture of the perfected, it is the supreme art of vanquishing ghosts. With evil dispelled, the true qi may be harnessed, and the slaying of malevolence tested—an essential method for the seeker.

Yet many dismiss it as too simple or minor, allowing it to be passed down carelessly. Thus, the divine incantation’s efficacy remains hidden, its power unexercised—a grave error.

*—Copied from the two manuscripts of Master Yang and Chancellor Yuan.*

Mount Fengdu lies in the north, in the Gui region. Above and below it are palaces of ghosts and spirits. On the mountain stand six palaces, and within its caverns lie six more, identical in name and form.

The first palace is called the Palace of Zhou, Severer of the Yin Heaven. Proceeding eastward, the second is the Palace of Tai Sha, the Solemn and Just Ancestor of Heaven. The third is the Palace of Ming Chen, the Enduring and Defiant Warrior City of Heaven. The fourth is the Palace of Tian Zhao, the Serene Illuminator of Sinful Qi. The fifth is the Palace of Zong Ling, the Sevenfold Nonconformity of Heaven. The sixth is the Palace of Gan Si, the Daring Controller of the Winding and Repeated Heaven.

These six palaces share the same names within and without. The first lies farthest west, with the rest arrayed eastward, all facing south. Each palace spans a thousand li, serving as the abode of all ghosts and spirits. Should one know the names of the six heavenly palace gates of Fengdu, no ghost will dare to harm them.

Earlier, it was said that "stone" refers to the palace names, while here and in the incantation, they are called gate names. The gates take their names from the palaces, hence the shared designation. When ghosts hear one recite these names, they recognize the speaker as a master of the heavenly palaces and dare not offend.

Before lying down, one should face north and recite the invocation thrice, softly. One may also slightly incline toward the Gui direction, reciting the full text once. Upon completion, tap the teeth six times, then recite it again—three times in total.

The incantation reads:
*"I am a disciple of the Most High, governing the Six Heavens below. The palaces of the Six Heavens are my domain—not only my domain, but the dominion of the Most High. I know the names of the Six Heavens’ palaces, and thus I attain long life. Should any dare to offend, the Most High shall sever your form. The first palace is named the Palace of Zhou, Severer of the Yin Heaven. Proceeding eastward, the second palace is named..."*

Each recitation consists of one hundred nineteen characters. Proceed in order until all six palaces are named. Then tap the teeth six times before lying down. After three recitations, one may attend to other matters—this practice alone suffices to repel all ghostly and malevolent qi.

At dusk, first recite the *Stone Stalagmite Text*, then read the *Ode to the Fengdu Palaces of the Pillars of Liang City*:
*"Zhou severs the dawn’s rule,
Solemn affairs weave the layered peaks.
Flaming as mist in the skies,
Bursting like radiant blossoms.
Wu Yang bears the divine blade,
Tian Zhao devours the clear river.
The Gate of Heaven overlooks the cinnabar well,
Cloud Gates rise in towering majesty.
The Sevenfold Nonconformity spreads its wondrous canopy,
The Winding and Repeated unfurl their demonic might.
The Six Heavens bar the northern path—
This is the abode of ghosts and spirits."*

The ode spans twenty thousand words; here, only the names of the Six Heavenly Palaces are excerpted. One may softly recite it at night—it, too, repels ghosts. Since it contains the names of the palace gates, ghosts fear it.

In the earlier text, the third palace is named *Wu Cheng* (Warrior City), while the ode calls it *Wu Yang* (Warrior Sun). This may indicate dual names or separate meanings—it is likely not an error.

*—Two passages from Master Zhong’s teachings. Copied from the two manuscripts of Master Yang and Chancellor Yuan.*

chunks.original_text: 夜行常当啄齿，啄齿亦无正限数也，杀鬼邪鬼常畏啄齿声，是故不犯人者也。 杀鬼则酆都太上所使取人者也，邪鬼则天地间精物魍魉害人者也。 若兼之以漱液咒说，益佳。 仙方云：常吞液叩齿，使人返少。 叩齿即无外鬼之侵，而内神常守； 吞液则和气常充，肌髓调润，故无病而不老矣。 右中君告。 杨君、掾两书本。 世有下土恶强之鬼，多作妇女以惑试人，世间老精强鬼善有斯变，非唯妇女，亦随人所好而化，从之皆使迷而不分。 始学者心未贞正，时怀邪念，多招斯事，故令却之。 若有此者，便闭气，思天关之中衡辅之星，星斗之象，璇衡辅弼皆在守寸中，杓指前具身神。 存守寸、明堂三宫及五藏中二十四神等也。 正颜色，定志意，熟视其规中珠子，珠子浊不明者，则鬼试也。 要当作方便近边，仍看其眼中，童子若暗者，知非是仙，则邪鬼耳。 亦可试以明镜照之也。 知鬼试，则思七星在面前，亦可在头上，以去之。 仍思向守寸中七星出覆头上，杓指前，击之，亦可心读天目、天蓬诸咒。 规中方而明者，仙道人也。 虽不方正而眼诤明者，亦是巽人，火日照之而无影，益为验也。 悟者便拜之，不悟者为试不过，若遇邪而谓之真人，亦是不过之例，子慎之焉。 此二事最为难辩，吾第二卷遵戒序中，论之备详矣。 右裴君告。 长史、掾两书本。
chunks.translated_text:
When traveling at night, one should always click the teeth—there is no fixed number of clicks. The sound of clicking teeth terrifies both *sha-ghosts* and *xie-ghosts*, ensuring they do not harm one. The *sha-ghosts* are those dispatched by the Supreme of Fengdu to claim lives, while the *xie-ghosts* are malevolent spirits and *wangliang* that lurk between heaven and earth to harm people. If one combines this with rinsing the mouth and reciting incantations, the effect is even better.

The *Immortal Methods* states: "Regularly swallowing saliva and clicking the teeth can make one revert to youth. Clicking the teeth prevents external ghosts from invading while keeping the inner spirits ever vigilant; swallowing saliva ensures harmonious qi is always abundant, nourishing the flesh and marrow, thus warding off illness and aging."

*—From Master Zhong’s teachings. Copied from the two manuscripts of Master Yang and Chancellor Yuan.*

In the mortal realm, there are fierce and malevolent ghosts of the lower earth who often appear as women to deceive and test people. These cunning ghosts and old spirits are adept at such transformations—not only as women but also taking forms based on one’s desires, leading those who follow them into confusion and delusion. Beginners whose minds are not yet steadfast and pure, harboring impure thoughts, often attract such encounters and must repel them.

If this occurs, hold your breath and visualize the *Central Balance* star within the *Celestial Pass*, the image of the *Big Dipper*, with the *Xuanji*, *Heng*, *Fu*, and *Bi* stars all guarding the *cun* position, its handle pointing forward to encompass the body’s spirits. Focus on the *cun*, the *Hall of Light’s* three palaces, and the twenty-four spirits within the five viscera. Compose your expression, steady your will, and gaze intently at the pupil of their eye. If the pupil is murky and unclear, it is a ghostly test.

One should then draw near with caution and observe their eyes—if the pupils appear dim, know they are not immortals but *xie-ghosts*. Alternatively, one may test them with a bright mirror. Upon recognizing a ghostly test, visualize the Seven Stars before your face or above your head to dispel it. One may also imagine the Seven Stars emerging from the *cun* to cover the head, the handle pointing forward, and strike them. Alternatively, silently recite incantations such as *Tianmu* or *Tianpeng*.

If the pupil is square and bright, they are a true immortal. Even if not perfectly square, if the eyes are clear and bright, they may still be a person of the *Xun* path. When illuminated by fire or sunlight, they cast no shadow—this further confirms their authenticity. Those who perceive this should bow in reverence; those who fail to recognize it have not passed the test. To mistake a *xie-ghost* for a true immortal is also a failure of discernment—take heed.

These two matters are the most difficult to distinguish. I have discussed them in exhaustive detail in the *Precepts and Admonitions* of my second volume.

*—From Master Pei’s teachings. Copied from the two manuscripts of the Chief Clerk and Chancellor.*
