chunks.original_text: 右前至此凡六事，并诛却精魔，防遏鬼试之道。 明堂内经开心辟妄符，王君撰用。 符在第六卷符图诀中，此即是入心一寸明堂之法，又应别有大经，今钞辟妄之事。 王君，上宰总真也。 开日旦，向王朱书，再拜服之。 平旦随月建，朱书白纸上，毕，左手执拜，拜毕乃祝，祝毕乃服之。 咒曰： 五神开心，彻听绝音，三魂摄精，尽守丹心，使我勿妄，五藏远寻。 拜毕祝，祝毕乃服，服毕咽液五过，叩齿五通，勿令人见。 若不用开日，以月旦、月十五日、二十七日，一月三服，一年便验秘符也。 谓不必知开日者，当以些二日耳，今自可兼用之，月五过或六过也。 右长史、掾两书本。 东华真人服日月之象上法，此则东华宫中男女以成真者，犹服之也。 故日芒之法，青君尚存。 男服日象，女服月象，日一勿废，使人聪明朗彻，五藏生华，魂魄制炼。 六府安和，长生不死之道。 当常以平旦东向，朱书日象於青纸上，左手执，存为日形如弹丸，赤色紫芒，乃服之，吞令入心，光明照彻。 毕可叩齿九通，咽，液九过。 女服月象，黄书青纸，右手执，亦东向服存入心。 回月，此两字是摹真本朱书。 右书日月象法，亦可圆书日也。 今既有方圆，又有日字不改，乃应依此，而紫文太玄符中有日字，乃圆作，既呼为日月象，便宜象於日月字，且古书偶月字，亦并似其形，故八体书势谓之象形也。 今若服圆 者，则 字亦应如此，皆别有立成法，在符图诀中。 右杨君书。 太虚真人南岳赤君内法曰：以月五日夜半，存日象在心中，日从口入也，使照一心之内，与日共光相合会也。 此坐卧任意，先存日赤色紫光九芒，忽来入口，径住心中，表裹洞光如一也。 毕，当觉心暖，霞晖映验。 初行止存令心暖，久久乃实觉其热，精心想之，易为感效也。 良久，乃祝曰： 太明育精，内炼丹心，光辉合映，神真来寻。 毕，咽液九过。 到十五日、二十五日、二十九日，复作如上法。 此三日皆奇，亦日数之所会也。 后云行之务欲数，不必数日者，则日日夜半常为之也。 使人开明聪察，百关解彻，面有玉光，体有金泽，行之十五年，太一遣保车来迎，上登太霄。 又一真本云：行之五年，太一遣玉保公下迎，寻彼当是脱车字耳。 此直云保车者，犹是玉保公车也。 行之务欲数，不必此数日作。 右一条云出太上消摩经中。
chunks.translated_text:
The preceding six matters all concern methods to expel demonic spirits and guard against ghostly trials. The *Mingtang Inner Scripture*’s *Heart-Opening Talisman to Dispel Delusion* was compiled and employed by Lord Wang. The talisman appears in the sixth volume’s *Talisman and Diagram Manual*; this is the method of the one-inch *Mingtang* within the heart. There should also be a separate major scripture, but here I excerpt only the matter of dispelling delusion.

Lord Wang is the Supreme Minister of the Assembly of Perfected. On the *kai*-day at dawn, face the direction of Wang, write in cinnabar, bow twice, and ingest it. At dawn, following the monthly branch, write in cinnabar on white paper, then hold it in the left hand, bow, recite the incantation, and ingest it. The incantation reads:

*"Five spirits open the heart,
piercing hearing, cutting off sound.
Three hun souls gather essence,
all guard the cinnabar heart.
Let me not be deluded;
five viscera seek afar."*

After bowing and reciting, ingest the talisman, then swallow saliva five times and click the teeth five times. Do not let others see. If the *kai*-day is not used, take it on the first, fifteenth, and twenty-seventh days of the month—three times a month. In one year, the secret talisman will prove efficacious. Those who do not know the *kai*-day may use these two days; now one may also take it five or six times a month.

*—From the two manuscripts of the Chief Clerk and Chancellor.*

The Eastern Flower Perfected’s method of ingesting the images of the sun and moon is a superior practice. In the Eastern Flower Palace, both men and women who attain perfection still employ it. Thus, the method of solar radiance remains preserved by the Azure Lord. Men ingest the solar image; women ingest the lunar image. Do not neglect this daily, for it sharpens clarity, illuminates the five viscera, refines the hun and po souls, harmonizes the six bowels, and is the Way of long life and deathlessness.

At dawn, face east, write the solar image in cinnabar on blue paper, hold it in the left hand, visualize it as a sun the size of a pellet, crimson with purple radiance, then ingest it, swallowing it into the heart so its light shines through. Afterward, click the teeth nine times and swallow saliva nine times. Women ingest the lunar image, writing in yellow on blue paper, holding it in the right hand, also facing east to ingest and visualize it entering the heart.

*Huimeng* (回月)—these two characters are copied from the original in cinnabar.

*—Method for writing the solar and lunar images. The sun may also be written as a circle. Now that both square and circular forms exist, along with the unaltered character for "sun," one should follow this. In the *Purple Text of the Great Mystery Talisman*, the character for "sun" is written as a circle. Since it is called the "image of the sun and moon," it should resemble the characters for sun and moon. Moreover, ancient scripts occasionally depict the character for "moon" in its shape, hence the *Eight Styles of Calligraphy* term it "pictographic." If one ingests the circular form, the character should likewise be written thus. All have established methods in the *Talisman and Diagram Manual.*

*—From Lord Yang’s manuscript.*

The Supreme Void Perfected, the Crimson Lord of Southern Marchmount, taught this inner method: On the fifth night of the month at midnight, visualize the solar image within the heart, as if the sun enters through the mouth, illuminating the heart’s interior to merge with the sun’s light. Whether sitting or lying down, first visualize the sun as crimson with nine rays of purple radiance, suddenly entering the mouth and settling in the heart, its inner and outer light merging as one. Afterward, one should feel the heart warm, suffused with rosy glow. Initially, merely visualize to warm the heart; over time, one will truly feel its heat. Focus the mind’s essence, and the effect will come easily.

After a long while, recite the incantation:
*"Great brightness nurtures essence,
internally refining the cinnabar heart.
Light and radiance merge,
divine perfected ones come seeking."*

Then swallow saliva nine times. On the fifteenth, twenty-fifth, and twenty-ninth days, repeat the above method. These three days are all auspicious, being conjunctions of solar and lunar cycles. Later texts state that one should practice frequently, not strictly on these days—indeed, one may perform this every midnight. It sharpens perception, unblocks all passages, bestows a jade-like glow to the face and a golden luster to the body. Practicing for fifteen years, the Great One will dispatch a *baoche* to welcome you, ascending to the Great Empyrean.

Another authentic manuscript states: After five years of practice, the Great One will send the Jade Guardian Duke to descend and welcome you—this likely refers to the *tuoche* (chariot). Here it simply says *baoche*, which is still the carriage of the Jade Guardian Duke. Practice frequently, not only on these days.

*—This passage is excerpted from the *Scripture of the Supreme High on Dispelling and Polishing.*"*

chunks.original_text: 此本出消摩智慧经中，赤君所钞用，故乃谓为内法。 长史书两本。 东华宫有服日月芒法，已成真人犹故服此，直存心中有日象，大如钱，在心中，赤色。 云直存者，今不知所由来，不从天下入口也，唯见心中有日形，虽大如钱，而不扁扁，犹如弹丸，径九分，正赤色。 又存日有九芒，向云赤色耳，不道是芒。 按后云月芒白，则日芒应紫色也。 从心上出喉至齿，此上存九色紫芒，悉上口中，锋头向齿而不出，于时亦闭口合齿也，唯是芒出耳，非日形俱上，所谓服日芒者矣。 而回还胃中，芒出时犹存日在心上，锋芒至於齿根下，尚缀日延亘喉胸之中，晖赫口齿之内，良久芒锋乃屈卷向后，从喉更下入胃，胃去心远近与喉一等，芒亦不加伸缩也。 良久，临目存自见心胃中分明，日故在心而芒居胃内，使光明流布，洞彻藏府，如此腹内亦应小热。 乃吐气漱液，服液三十九过止。 云吐气者，向初存时既闭口合齿，又当闭气，须存想竟，乃通气开齿，漱满口中津液，乃服咽之，存液亦作紫色。 一日三为之，此当以平旦东向，日中南向，哺时西向，并平坐临目，闭气乃存。 行之一年疾病除，五年身有光彩，十八年必得道，行日中无影，辟百邪千恶灾气。 若服日月之形，例不至十八年，此既是芒，所以小缓。 日月常在身中，与形合照，故能无影，万神映朗，岂邪恶之敢干乎。 常存日在心，存月在泥丸中。 此又云常存者，明非服时不出於口故也。 夜服月华如服日法，存日月并不须见其真形，但止室中。 月既用夜，亦可卧存之，又应三过以戊子丑时也。 向云常在泥丸，当是上丹田之泥丸宫也，玄丹亦名泥丸。 又玄真存月在明堂宫，此皆别用耳。 今日既在於心，居真人之府，则月亦应在赤子之房，於事相符，故令存在上丹田也。 存月十芒白色，月色但黄，此白色，正是道月有十芒，芒白色耳，又明月形之不下口也，存月径一寸。 从脑中下入喉，头中九宫通居脑内耳，今月既在泥丸，故可得呼为脑，且又欲明不出於外而下也。 又九宫唯泥丸宫下有穴通喉耳，当存十芒从泥丸直下，所通鼻内孔中，各使五芒出於一孔而入喉中，锋亦向齿。 芒亦不出齿而回入胃。 此时亦闭口齿如前，其芒令停口中，使光明充满，乃回向后而下入胃，因吐气漱咽白液，亦三十九过，毕，觉脑中相连之芒欻然消尽。 右南极夫人所告，云此方诸真人法，出大智慧经上中篇，常能行之，保见太平。 西城王君曰：行此日在心，月在泥丸之道，谓省易可得旨行，无中废绝者也。 言此无祝说，又不须见日月，存思法亦不难，於人间而不患多方也。 除身三尸百疾千恶，炼魂制魄之道也。 日月常照形中，则鬼无藏形，形常为日月所栖，则邪鬼无所隐伏，故能不疾。 青君今故行之，吾即其人也。 此智慧经事，非止是方诸法，故总真亦复用之。 行此道，亦不妨行宝书所服日月法也，兼行益善也。 宝书日月，谓五老宝经，即紫文三魂之法，此既内外之异，故可兼行。 今平旦及夕，当先於室中存服芒，至日月出时，乃行精霞之法也。 今以告子，告杨君也。 脱可密示有心者耳。 令示长史掾。 仙人一日一夕行千事，初不觉劳，明勤道之至，生不可失矣。 既已称仙，其体理自堪劳，此谓当仙之人耳。
chunks.translated_text:
This version originates from the *Scripture of Wisdom and Dispelling* and was excerpted and employed by Lord Chi, hence it is termed an "inner method." The Prefect copied two versions.

The Eastern Flower Palace possesses the method of ingesting the radiance of the sun and moon, which even perfected immortals continue to practice. It involves simply visualizing a sun within the heart, the size of a coin, crimson in color. As for the term "simply visualize," its origin is now unknown—it does not enter through the mouth but is perceived solely within the heart as a solar form. Though no larger than a coin, it is not flat but spherical, like a pellet, nine *fen* in diameter, of a pure crimson hue. One further visualizes the sun as having nine rays, which are also said to be crimson, though not explicitly called "rays." According to later passages, the moon’s rays are white, so the sun’s rays should be violet. From the heart, it ascends through the throat to the teeth, where one visualizes nine violet rays, all rising into the mouth with their tips pointing toward the teeth but not emerging. At this time, the mouth is closed and the teeth are clenched; only the rays emerge, not the solar form itself—this is what is meant by "ingesting the sun’s rays." The rays then return to the stomach. While the rays ascend, the sun remains visualized above the heart, its radiant tips extending to the roots of the teeth, lingering within the throat and chest, illuminating the mouth and teeth. After a long while, the ray-tips curl backward, descending from the throat into the stomach. The distance from the stomach to the heart is equal to that from the throat to the heart, and the rays neither extend nor retract. After some time, with eyes closed, one clearly perceives within the heart and stomach: the sun remains in the heart while the rays reside in the stomach, causing light to flow and suffuse the organs, making the abdomen slightly warm. One then exhales, rinses the mouth with saliva, and swallows the fluid thirty-nine times before stopping. The exhalation refers to the initial visualization, where the mouth and teeth are closed and breath is held. Only after completing the visualization does one release the breath, open the teeth, rinse the mouth with saliva, and swallow it, visualizing the fluid as violet. This is performed three times daily: at dawn facing east, at noon facing south, and at dusk facing west, each time sitting upright, closing the eyes, holding the breath, and visualizing. Practicing this for one year dispels illness; for five years, the body gains a radiant luster; for eighteen years, one attains the Dao, casts no shadow at noon, and repels all malevolent spirits, evil influences, and calamitous qi. If one ingests the forms of the sun and moon directly, the time required is less than eighteen years; since this method involves only the rays, it is slightly slower.

The sun and moon constantly reside within the body, merging with one’s form to illuminate it, hence the absence of shadow. With all spirits radiant and clear, how could evil dare to approach? One should constantly visualize the sun in the heart and the moon in the *niwan* (Mud-Pill Palace). The phrase "constantly visualize" clarifies that this is not limited to the time of ingestion, as the sun and moon do not leave the mouth. At night, one ingests the moon’s essence in the same manner as the sun, visualizing both without needing to see their true forms—simply remain indoors. Since the moon is used at night, one may also practice while lying down, performing it three times during the hours of *wu*, *zi*, and *chou*. The earlier reference to the moon residing in the *niwan* refers to the *niwan* Palace of the Upper Cinnabar Field; the Mysterious Cinnabar is also called *niwan*. Elsewhere, the *Xuan Zhen* method visualizes the moon in the Hall of Brightness, but these are separate practices. Here, since the sun resides in the heart, the seat of the perfected, the moon should correspondingly dwell in the Chamber of the Red Child, aligning with the principle—hence it is placed in the Upper Cinnabar Field.

One visualizes the moon’s ten rays as white. Though the moon’s color is yellow, these rays are white, precisely the ten rays of the Daoist moon, which are white. This further clarifies that the moon’s form does not descend through the mouth. The visualized moon is one *cun* in diameter. From the brain, it descends into the throat. The Nine Palaces all reside within the brain, so since the moon is in the *niwan*, it may be called the brain. Moreover, this emphasizes that it does not exit externally but descends inward. Among the Nine Palaces, only the *niwan* Palace has an aperture connecting to the throat. One visualizes the ten rays descending directly from the *niwan* through the nasal passages, with five rays emerging from each nostril into the throat, their tips also pointing toward the teeth. The rays do not emerge from the teeth but return to the stomach. At this time, the mouth and teeth are closed as before, and the rays are held within the mouth, filling it with light. They then turn backward and descend into the stomach. One exhales, rinses with white fluid, and swallows thirty-nine times. Upon completion, the rays connected to the brain abruptly vanish.

The above was transmitted by the Lady of the Southern Culmen, who stated that this method is practiced by all perfected immortals and derives from the upper and middle chapters of the *Great Scripture of Wisdom*. Those who practice it diligently will witness the Great Peace. Lord Wang of the Western City said: "Practicing this method of the sun in the heart and the moon in the *niwan* is simple and easy to grasp, with no risk of abandonment midway. It requires no incantations or invocations, nor does one need to see the sun and moon—the visualization is not difficult, and it does not burden one with excessive methods while in the mortal realm. It is the way to eliminate the Three Corpses, the hundred illnesses, and the thousand evils, and to refine the hun and po souls. When the sun and moon constantly illuminate the body, ghosts have no place to hide; when one’s form is perpetually inhabited by the sun and moon, evil spirits cannot lurk—hence one remains free from illness. The Azure Lord now practices this, and I am that very person."

This matter from the *Scripture of Wisdom* is not limited to this single method; even the *Zong Zhen* also employs it. Practicing this method does not hinder the ingestion of the sun and moon as described in the *Precious Scriptures*; indeed, combining them is even better. The "sun and moon of the Precious Scriptures" refers to the *Five Elders’ Precious Canon*, specifically the method of the Three Hun in the *Purple Texts*. Since this method differs in its internal and external aspects, it may be practiced concurrently. At dawn and dusk, one should first visualize and ingest the rays indoors, then, when the sun and moon appear, proceed with the method of the radiant mist.

I now reveal this to you—this is addressed to Lord Yang. It may be discreetly shared with those of sincere intent. Instruct the Prefect’s aide accordingly. An immortal performs a thousand tasks in a single day and night without feeling weary, demonstrating the utmost diligence in the Dao—such an opportunity in life must not be squandered. Once one is called an immortal, the body naturally endures labor; this refers to those destined for immortality.

chunks.original_text: 凡始学既未甚贞强，其质自易为劬倦，久久习之，乃可闲便，不得初决努力，而后稍致怠替。 每从少起，渐试进之，当令一法有常，不可苟贪多尚高也。 夫修道乃不患多，但使得其次序，不至乱杂耳，所谓非冥冥之无贯，行冥贯之无序矣。 万劫结缘，今有此生，此生一失，复应万劫，何可不勇猛精勤，使於此遂常生乎。 右杨书。 童初监范某云：所服三气之法：存青气、白气、赤气各如线，从东方日下来，直入口中，常以日旦向日，若阴雨亦存对之，坐立任意，临目存此三色气并列，青在左，以次状如悬芒，合来入口，使三气之彼根犹缀在日中。 挹之九十过，自饱便止。 一吸一咽为一抱也。 咽气入喉，使分流诸藏府内，至数欲讫，渐渐歇尽而止。 为之十年，身中自有三气。 谓身中常有三色之气出於头上也。 此高元君太素内景法，即上清太素三元君之一小法也。 旦旦为之，临目施行，视日益佳，其法鲜而其事验，许侯可为之。 按此是太素之法，又令仙侯为之，则亦不为下，而范氏受用止得监者，当其所修诸道不多，唯得一法故耳。 今令许用此，盖以相扶助，非为专定业也。 右中君言。 杨书。
chunks.translated_text:
For beginners whose resolve is not yet firm, their constitution naturally inclines toward weariness. With prolonged practice, however, one may attain ease and proficiency. One must not exert excessive effort at first only to grow lax later. Proceed gradually from small beginnings, ensuring each method is practiced with constancy. One should not hastily covet quantity or aspire to lofty heights.

In cultivating the Dao, the concern is not with multiplicity but with maintaining proper sequence to avoid disorder and confusion. As the saying goes: "Without the obscurity of coherence, one practices the coherence of obscurity without order."

Eons of karmic affinity have brought forth this present life. To lose this life is to await another ten thousand eons—how can one not be fiercely diligent, striving to attain eternal life herein?

---

**Lord Yang’s Letter**

Supervisor Fan of Tongchu states the method of ingesting the Three Qi: Visualize a blue qi, a white qi, and a red qi, each like a thread descending from the rising sun in the east and entering the mouth. At dawn, face the sun; if overcast or rainy, visualize facing it. Whether seated or standing, with eyes closed, envision these three colored qi aligned—blue on the left, then the others—appearing like suspended rays converging into the mouth, their roots still tethered to the sun. Draw them in ninety times, ceasing once satiated. One inhalation and one swallow count as one cycle. As the qi enters the throat, guide it to flow into the organs and viscera. When the count nears completion, gradually cease until the qi is fully absorbed.

After ten years of practice, the Three Qi will naturally reside within the body, manifesting as three-colored qi emanating from the crown of the head. This is the *High Prime Lord’s Method of the Inner Radiance of Grand Simplicity*, a minor practice of the *Supreme Clarity Lords of the Three Primes*.

Perform this daily with eyes closed, facing the sun for optimal results. Though the method is subtle, its effects are verified. Lord Xu may practice it.

This is a method of *Grand Simplicity*; if the Immortal Marquis also practices it, it is by no means inferior. However, Supervisor Fan’s attainment is limited to supervision, for among the many Daoist practices he has cultivated, he has mastered but this one. Now instructing Lord Xu to employ this method serves as mutual support, not as a fixed primary practice.

chunks.original_text: 含真台女真张微子所受东华玉妃某服雾法：常以平旦，於寝静之中，即就所卧之室也。 坐卧任己，先闭目内视，仿髴如见五藏，当以此存五藏形色分开如法。 毕，口呼出气二十四过，临目为之，此因呼出五藏五色气，使五气俱一时出，凡二十四过，向闭目存五藏，五藏具毕，乃小开，临目而呼出气。 使目见五色之气相缠绕。 在面上郁然，前直云呼出气，而此云五色，五色非应他来，犹是向五藏五色耳，使五气纷错相纠，共相冠头面之上也。 咽入口内此五色气五十过，向五色凝郁面上，良久乃更内之，当并吸使入口而咽之也，觉引天地间五色气，又同与面上者相交合，俱还藏中，凡五气出内，皆各随其色还本藏。 主十咽，从肺心肝肾脾为次也。 毕咽液六十过。 正应空咽液耳。 乃微祝曰： 太霞发晖，灵雾四迁，结气宛屈，五色洞天，神烟含启，金石华真，蔼郁紫空，炼形保全，出景藏幽，五灵化分，合明扇虚，时乘六云，保摄我身，上升九天。 毕，又叩齿七通，咽液七过，乃开目，事讫。 前云服雾之法，其序云：雾者是山泽水火之华精，金石之盈气。 而今存服犹是我五藏中之气者，何也。 谓向呼出二十四气，使与外雾相交，两烟合体，然后服之，故顿服五十过，则是服雾气得二十六通矣。 此道神妙，神州玄都多有得此术者，尔可行此耶。 亦告杨君也。 久久行之，常乘云雾而游也。 又云：久服之，则能散形入空，与云气合体。 右中君告。 杨书。
chunks.translated_text:
**Method of Ingesting Mist, Conferred by the Perfected Lady Zhang Weizi of the Chamber of Embracing the Real upon the Jade Consort of the Eastern Flower**

At dawn’s first light, within the stillness of your chamber—where you lie abed—sit or recline as you prefer. First, close your eyes and turn your gaze inward, faintly perceiving the five viscera. Visualize their forms and colors distinctly, each in proper order. When this is complete, exhale through the mouth twenty-four times, performing this with eyes still closed. With each exhalation, expel the five-colored qi of the five viscera, so that all five qi emerge simultaneously—twenty-four cycles in all. As you exhale, maintain the inward vision of the five viscera until all are fully perceived. Then, slightly parting your eyes, continue exhaling until you see the five-colored qi intertwining before your face, swirling thickly above it.

Though the text earlier speaks of exhaling qi, here it specifies five colors. These do not come from without but are the very five-colored qi of the five viscera, now tangled and interwoven, crowning your head and face. Next, draw this five-colored qi into your mouth and swallow it fifty times. As the five hues congeal and linger above your face, wait a while, then inhale them together, guiding them into your mouth to be swallowed. You will feel the five-colored qi of Heaven and Earth merging with that upon your face, both returning to their respective viscera. Each of the five qi, upon exiting and reentering, follows its own color back to its source. Perform ten swallows in sequence, beginning with the lungs, then heart, liver, kidneys, and spleen.

Afterward, swallow saliva sixty times—this refers to the act of swallowing emptily. Then recite the subtle invocation:

*"Radiant dawn-glow arises,
Spirit-mist drifts on all sides.
Coiling qi bends and twists,
Five colors fill the cavern-heaven.
Divine smoke unfurls,
Gold and stone bloom with true essence.
Purple emptiness gathers in mist,
Refining form to preserve wholeness.
Emerging light conceals the hidden,
Five numina transform and divide.
Conjoined brightness fans the void,
Riding the six clouds in due season.
Guard and embrace this body of mine,
Ascending to the Nine Heavens."*

When finished, strike the teeth together seven times, swallow saliva seven times, then open your eyes. The ritual is complete.

The preceding text describes the *Method of Ingesting Mist*, and its preface states: *"Mist is the essence-flower of mountains, marshes, water, and fire, the overflowing qi of metal and stone."* Yet here, what is visualized and ingested is the qi of one’s own five viscera. Why? Because the twenty-four exhalations earlier intermingle with the external mist, merging the two smokes into one body. Thus, when you swallow fifty times in rapid succession, you are in truth ingesting mist-qi twenty-six times over.

This Way is wondrous and numinous. Many in the Mystic Capital of the Divine Continent have attained this art. Might you, too, practice it? This is also addressed to Lord Yang. With long and steadfast practice, you will come to ride clouds and mist in your travels. It is further said: *"With prolonged ingestion, one may disperse the form into emptiness, merging body with cloud and qi."*

**Middle Lord’s Discourse.**
**Lord Yang’s Letter.**

ough the method is subtle, its effects are verified. Lord Xu may practice it.

This is a method of *Grand Simplicity*; if the Immortal Marquis also practices it, it is by no means inferior. However, Supervisor Fan’s attainment is limited to supervision, for among the many Daoist practices he has cultivated, he has mastered but this one. Now instructing Lord Xu to employ this method serves as mutual support, not as a fixed primary practice.

chunks.original_text: 杜广平所受介瑛玄白之术，一名胎精中景玄白内法。 常旦旦坐卧任意，存泥丸中有黑气，存心中有白气，存脐中有黄气，此三处犹谓三宫中也，亦是三一之别道，但气色为异耳。 三气俱生如云以覆身，各从其初处出，如小豆，乃惭大，以覆冠一身耳。 因变成火，火又绕身，内虽变作火，外犹有三气也。 身通洞彻，内外如一。 火与气俱烧炼身，表裹照彻也。 旦行至向中乃止。 诸修行之中，唯法为久，存思气火，便宜安详，渐渐变化，及炼身之后，弥使良久，状如眠寐，不复觉有四体乃佳。 於是服气一百二十，都毕。 亦存服向之三色之气，各四十过也。 道正如此，使人长生不死，辟却万害。 所谓知白守黑，欲死不得，知黑守白，万邪消却。 白黑即向三色之气，所谓玄白也，此语亦引五千文中之辞也。 尤禁六畜肉、五辛之味，当别寝处静思，尤忌房室，房室即死。 此道与守一相似，但为径要以减之耳。 谓径要省略，故为减耳。 忌房室甚於守一，守一之忌在於节之耳。 守一既许有儿，故不为都断也。 初存气出如小豆，渐大冲天，三气缠咽绕身，共同成一混，忽生火在三烟之内。 又合景以炼一身，一身之裹，五藏照彻，此亦要道也。 前法小略，故复重说，存思之事，当令如此。 此不死之学，未及於仙道也，自可兼行，以除万邪，却千害，行之三十年，遁形隐身，日行五百里。 此道甚下，修之至久，若修行余事，便不得用也，才浅分少者，宜令守此耳，非高学之所务矣。 若欲守玄白者，当与其经，经亦少许耳。 如此玄白，复别有正经，亦应有祝，此盖其钞略，犹如玄真事耳，此道犹是太清家旧法，小君今言，似令告寅驮也。 右保命告。 掾书。
chunks.translated_text:
Du Guangping’s received technique of *Jieying Xuanbai* is also called the *Tai Jing Zhong Jing Xuanbai Inner Method*. At all times, whether sitting or lying down, visualize as you will: within the *Niwan* there is black qi, within the heart there is white qi, and within the navel there is yellow qi. These three places are also called the Three Palaces, and they are another branch of the Three Ones, differing only in the colors of their qi. The three qi arise together like clouds to cover the body, each emerging from its original place as small as a bean, then gradually growing to envelop the crown and the entire body. They then transform into fire, which coils around the body. Though internally it has become fire, externally the three qi remain. The body becomes pervasively luminous, inner and outer as one. The fire and qi together refine the body, illuminating it inside and out. Practice this from dawn until midday, then cease.

Among all cultivation methods, this one endures the longest. In visualizing qi and fire, proceed with calm and composure, allowing gradual transformation. After refining the body, persist even longer, as if in slumber, until you no longer sense the four limbs—this is best. Then ingest qi one hundred and twenty times in total, completing the practice. Also visualize and ingest the three colored qi from before, forty times each.

This is the true Way, enabling one to attain longevity and immortality, warding off all harm. As it is said: *"Know the white, guard the black—death cannot come; know the black, guard the white—all evil dissipates."* The white and black refer to the three colored qi mentioned earlier, the so-called *Xuanbai*. This saying is also drawn from the *Five Thousand Characters*.

Strictly avoid the flesh of the six livestock and the flavors of the five pungents. Sleep apart in quietude to focus the mind, and above all, shun the bedchamber—for the bedchamber brings death. This method resembles *Shouyi* but is more direct and essential, thus simplified. It is abbreviated for efficiency. The prohibition against the bedchamber is even stricter than in *Shouyi*, where restraint is the key. *Shouyi* permits having children, so it does not require complete abstinence.

At first, visualize the qi emerging like small beans, gradually growing to pierce the heavens. The three qi coil around the throat and entwine the body, merging into one. Suddenly, fire arises within the three smokes, uniting with the inner radiance to refine the entire body. Within, the five viscera become luminous—this is the essential Way.

The previous method was slightly abridged, so it is restated here. Visualization must be thus. This is the study of deathlessness, though it does not yet reach the Dao of immortality. It may be practiced alongside other methods to dispel all evil, repel a thousand harms, and after thirty years of cultivation, conceal the form and hide the body, traveling five hundred *li* in a day.

This Way is rather humble. If pursued to its utmost, other practices cannot be undertaken simultaneously. Those of shallow capacity and limited destiny should adhere to this. It is not the pursuit of advanced scholars. If one wishes to guard *Xuanbai*, one should receive its scripture, which is brief. This *Xuanbai* has its own proper canon and should also have its invocations. What is recorded here is but an excerpt, much like the matters of *Xuan Zhen*. This method remains an old technique of the *Taiqing* tradition.

chunks.original_text: 君曰：欲得延年，当洗面精心，日出二丈，服日后乃可为之。 面向日，口吐死气，鼻吸日精，须鼻得嚏便止，是为气通，口常吐四时死浊之气，鼻吸引丹霞之精，须臾自嚏乃止。 此亦颇类上法，但无祝说耳。 以补精复胎，长生之方也。 君曰：欲使心正，常当以日出三丈，取嚏竟，仍复为之。 错手着两肩上，左手在上，不可误也。 以日当心，此当正心以对日，存日亦正对於心也。 心中觉暖，则心正矣。 亦存日之精晖来入心，故觉其微暖也。 常能行之佳。 其说有人心不正者，亟为邪事所动，所以真人令向日观之，既见有偏，故授此法，大体与日光入心理同，今无论正与不正，常行此，自为佳术也。 右二条裴君授。 长史、掾两书本。
chunks.translated_text:
The Master says: If one wishes to attain longevity, one must wash the face and purify the heart. When the sun has risen two *zhang*, and only after it has fully ascended, may this be practiced. Face the sun, exhale the dead qi from the mouth, and inhale the sun’s essence through the nose. When a sneeze is induced, cease—this is called the passage of qi. The mouth should always exhale the dead, turbid qi of the four seasons, while the nose draws in the essence of cinnabar clouds, stopping only when a sneeze naturally occurs. This method closely resembles the preceding one, though it lacks invocations. It is a means to replenish essence, restore the embryo, and attain longevity.

The Master says: To rectify the heart, one should begin when the sun has risen three *zhang*. After inducing the sneeze, repeat the practice. Cross the hands upon the shoulders, with the left hand above—this must not be mistaken. Let the sun align with the heart, so that the heart is centered directly toward the sun, and the sun, in turn, is envisioned as directly facing the heart. When warmth is felt within the heart, the heart is rectified. This warmth arises from the sun’s radiant essence entering the heart. It is excellent to practice this regularly. Some say that when the heart is not rectified, it is swiftly swayed by wayward affairs. Thus, the Perfected One instructs one to face the sun and observe it. Upon perceiving any deviation, this method is taught. In essence, it aligns with the principle of sunlight entering the heart. Now, regardless of whether the heart is rectified or not, practicing this consistently is itself an excellent technique.

chunks.original_text: 右前至此几九事，并服御吐纳，存注烟霞之道也。 右众真授诀三条，凡五十二事。 登真隐诀卷中竟 #1『名』字下疑有脱漏字。 登真隐诀卷下 诵黄庭经法 拜祝法 《三九素语玉精真诀》曰：中品目有三九素语，魏传目有玉精真诀。 三九素语即应是此经也，但未行世，世中有伪者，无此诀也。 诵东华玉篇《黄庭内景经》，云十读四拜。 本经此中云朝太上，今略去三字，而后显北向礼祝太上，不当昧前旨耶。 先谒太帝，后北向，经序无旨诀也。 谓言黄庭前序不说朝谒之法。 按此经中十四字，已足明其事，何假复须发序。 消摩云讽及於此，上朝四方，亦复应须别诀耳。 今黄庭之诀，乃出素语，高下之品，殊似不类矣。 太帝东，应朝礼。 太帝，紫晨君也。 按入道望云，令东南望扶#1桑太帝三素飞云。 又方诸在会稽东南，其东北则有汤谷。 又云入停山在沧浪之东北，蓬莱之东南。 入泞山即太帝所治处也。 又清虚王君东行，渡启明沧浪，登广桑山，入始晖庭，谒太帝君，如此则扶#2桑在汤谷东南，於金陵正东亦小南看矣。 且玉箓太帝无紫晨之号，今此所云皆以相乖矣，若必用之，故宜正东向也，所以读经正东向，而仍云先谒太帝者，明在东矣。 回北礼祝太上矣。 上清在北，故经言后北向也。 先行其轻，乃造其重也。 十读既竟，起向太帝再拜。 拜毕长跪，瞑目祝曰： 小兆某甲谨读金书玉经，东华谓之玉篇，今启太帝而云玉经，将不滥耶。 十转既周，乞登龙耕，经序本云万遍方得彻视五藏而已，今始得十转，便乞登龙耕，如违旨。 此法不如余祝，发始便得滥希神仙，及有遍数之阙也。 天神下降，役使六丁，七祖飞升，我登上清。 按黄庭是调和五藏，制练魂魄，本非升化七祖之法。 又内黄庭止是不死而已，何上清之可腾乎。 且臣而称我，亦乖谦请之礼。 飞步祝以名与我相杂者，此是祝星时以我对彼恶人耳，非如今亲对太帝而自称也。 毕，开目咽液十过，叩齿九通。 若以十咽为十遍，则叩齿亦宜同。 今九过之义，义无所取。 次北向再拜，长跪祝曰： 上皇太真，使我升虚，上皇太真，非玉晨之目，使我升虚，事同前讥。 太帝称臣，而太上更不可，真法朝祝，皆止姓名，无臣我之例。 清斋澡炼，诵咏金书，太上谓之琴心黄庭，而乃说扶#3 桑之目，何期两祝皆乖耶。 七玄披散，上朝帝庐，诵大洞万过，七祖方得九宫之仙，今咏黄庭十遍，而便乞朝宴帝庐，不亦过乎。 延年长存，刻名箓书。 前乞升虚，后乞延年，则初得高真，末还地仙耶。 毕，临目叩齿九通，咽液十过。 前篇开目，后章临目，叩咽之法，又前后倒用，两法非异，而俯仰不同，统体而论，皆违真例，恐是后学浅才，率意立此，不能诠简事义，故多致违舛，相承崇异，莫能证辩。 今始学之子，若欲按此，亦不为所妨，要非吾心之所了，若必目观，真书所不论耳。 都毕后，还常所转经也。 存神别法 清虚真人曰：凡修《黄庭内经》，应依帝君填神混化玄真之道。 按裴君学道，及有所受说，都不阙黄庭家事，此云帝君填神混化玄真，是今世中伪经，窃用紫度炎光卷中法，其神形长短祝说皆同，乃又因伪以立伪，愆妄之甚者也。 今所以犹载於此卷者，恐后学尚之子，脱於余处所得，不料真伪，言是要诀，谨事存修，则为熏犹相混，有致真之失，故显示其非，令有以悟耳。

The preceding entries, totaling nine matters, all pertain to the Dao of ingestion, exhalation and inhalation, and the visualization of mist and clouds.

**Three entries of oral instructions transmitted by the Perfected Ones, comprising fifty-two matters in all.**
*Master Deng’s Hidden Instructions on Ascending to Perfection, Scroll the Middle, concludes here.* #1 (Note: A character appears to be missing beneath 『名』.)

---

**Master Deng’s Hidden Instructions on Ascending to Perfection, Scroll the Lower**

**Method for Reciting the *Yellow Court Scripture***
**Method for Worship and Invocation**

The *Three-Nine Plain Speech Jade Essence True Instructions* states: The middle grade includes the *Three-Nine Plain Speech*, while the *Wei Transmissions* include the *Jade Essence True Instructions*. The *Three-Nine Plain Speech* likely refers to this scripture, though it has not circulated in the world. Spurious versions exist, but none contain these instructions.

When reciting the *Eastern Florescence Jade Chapters of the Yellow Court Inner Radiance Scripture*, it is said to perform ten recitations and four bows. This scripture states, “At dawn, face the Supreme,” but here the three characters “face the Supreme” are omitted, and later it directs one to turn north to worship and invoke the Supreme. Does this not obscure the original intent? First, one pays homage to the Supreme Emperor, then turns north—yet the scripture’s preface contains no such instructions. It is said that the preface to the *Yellow Court* does not describe the method of paying homage. However, the fourteen characters within this scripture suffice to clarify the matter; why rely on an additional preface? Some commentaries suggest that upon reaching this point in recitation, one should face the four directions in homage—this, too, would require separate instructions. The present instructions for the *Yellow Court* derive from the *Plain Speech*, yet the high and low grades seem incongruous.

The Supreme Emperor resides in the east; thus, homage should be paid facing east. The Supreme Emperor is the Purple Dawn Lord. According to the *Entering the Dao and Gazing at Clouds*, one is to gaze southeast toward the Fusang and the Supreme Emperor amidst the Three Plain Flying Clouds. Moreover, the Fangzhu is located southeast of Kuaiji, while its northeast holds the Tang Valley. It is also said that Entering Stillness Mountain lies northeast of the Canglang, southeast of Penglai. Entering Ning Mountain is the abode governed by the Supreme Emperor. Furthermore, the Perfected Lord of Pure Emptiness, traveling east, crossed the Canglang at the Break of Dawn, ascended Broad Mulberry Mountain, entered the Court of First Radiance, and paid homage to the Supreme Emperor Lord. Thus, Fusang lies southeast of the Tang Valley, and from Jinling, it appears slightly south of due east. However, in the *Jade Register*, the Supreme Emperor bears no title of Purple Dawn. The present account contradicts these sources. If one must adhere to it, one should face due east. Therefore, when reciting the scripture, one faces east, and the instruction to first pay homage to the Supreme Emperor confirms its eastern location. Only afterward does one turn north to worship and invoke the Supreme. The Upper Clarity resides in the north, hence the scripture’s later directive to face north. One first performs the lighter act before proceeding to the weightier.

Upon completing the ten recitations, rise and bow twice toward the Supreme Emperor. After bowing, kneel lengthily, close the eyes, and invoke:

*“This humble servant [Name] respectfully recites the Golden Writ and Jade Scripture, which the Eastern Florescence calls the Jade Chapters. Now, invoking the Supreme Emperor, I refer to it as the Jade Scripture—is this not an overreach? Having completed ten cycles, I beseech to ascend the Dragon Plow. The scripture’s preface states that only after ten thousand recitations may one clearly perceive the five viscera, yet here, after a mere ten cycles, one begs to ascend the Dragon Plow—does this not defy the intent? This invocation is inferior to others, for from the outset it presumptuously seeks immortality and omits the required number of recitations. May the celestial spirits descend, command the Six Dings, cause my seven ancestors to ascend, and allow me to ascend to the Upper Clarity.”*

Yet the *Yellow Court* harmonizes the five viscera and refines the hun and po—it is not a method for ascending the seven ancestors. Moreover, the *Inner Yellow Court* merely ensures immortality; how could it enable ascent to the Upper Clarity? Furthermore, referring to oneself as “I” while addressing a superior violates the rites of humble supplication. The invocation to “fly and step” intermingles one’s name with “I,” a practice used when invoking stars to counter malevolent forces—not when directly addressing the Supreme Emperor.

Upon finishing, open the eyes, swallow saliva ten times, and click the teeth nine times. If ten swallows constitute ten cycles, then the teeth-clicking should match. The meaning of nine cycles here is unclear.

Next, turn north, bow twice, and kneel lengthily to invoke:

*“Supreme August Perfect One, enable me to ascend to emptiness.” The Supreme August Perfect One is not an epithet of the Jade Dawn. “Enable me to ascend to emptiness” repeats the earlier error. In true methods of homage and invocation, only one’s name is used—there is no precedent for “your servant” or “I.” After purifying through fasting and refinement, reciting the Golden Writ, the Supreme calls it the *Zither-Heart Yellow Court*, yet here it speaks of Fusang—why do both invocations deviate? “May my seven ancestors disperse and ascend to the Emperor’s abode; after reciting the *Great Cavern* ten thousand times, may my seven ancestors attain immortality in the Nine Palaces.” Yet here, after reciting the *Yellow Court* ten times, one begs to attend the Emperor’s banquet—is this not excessive? “Prolong my years and preserve my existence; inscribe my name in the register.” First, one seeks to ascend to emptiness, then to prolong life—does this mean attaining high perfection only to revert to earthly immortality?

Upon finishing, close the eyes, click the teeth nine times, and swallow saliva ten times. In the previous section, the eyes were opened; here, they are closed. The methods of clicking and swallowing are reversed, and though the two practices are not distinct, their postures differ. Taken as a whole, they violate true precedents. This likely stems from later students of shallow talent who established these methods arbitrarily, failing to distill the essence of the matter and thus introducing many contradictions. Successive generations have revered these deviations without scrutiny. For beginners who wish to follow them, no harm is done, but they do not align with my understanding. If one must observe them, they are not addressed in the true scriptures.

After completing all rites, return to the usual recitation of the scripture.

**Alternative Method for Visualizing the Spirits**
The Perfected Lord of Pure Emptiness states: In cultivating the *Yellow Court Inner Scripture*, one should follow the Dao of the Lord Emperor’s “Filling the Spirits and Blending the Mysterious True.”

According to Master Pei’s studies and transmissions, nothing is lacking in the *Yellow Court* tradition. Yet this “Filling the Spirits and Blending the Mysterious True” is a spurious scripture of the present age, plagiarizing the method from the *Purple Capital’s Flame and Light Scroll*. Its descriptions of the spirits’ forms, lengths, invocations, and instructions are identical—thus, it compounds falsehood with further falsehood, a grave error.

The reason it is still included in this scroll is to prevent later students who may obtain it elsewhere from mistaking it for the true method. If they practice it diligently, believing it to be an essential instruction, they risk confusing the genuine with the spurious, leading to the loss of the true Dao. Therefore, its falsity is exposed here to awaken them.

chunks.original_text: 读竟，礼祝毕，正坐东向，临目内存身神形色长短大小，呼其名字，还填本宫。 不修此法，虽诵万遍，真神不守，终无感效，亦损气疲神，无益於年命也。 今故抄经中要节相示。 黄庭之序，已备载诵读之法，若此二事不知修者，便无感效，则兼应说之，乃更论怖畏疾病及遇秽之法，而了不及此神王。 王君宁当不欲分明指的垂告耶，经如此事，理不尽便，都无可修者矣。 平坐临目，叩齿三十六通，乃存神，既非制邪大祝，乃后四九叩齿存神，如此经例所无也。 发神苍华字太元，形长二寸一分； 脑神精根字泥丸，形长一寸二分； 眼神明上字英玄，形长三寸； 鼻神玉垄字灵坚，形长二寸五分； 耳神空闲字幽田，形长三寸一分； 舌神通命字正伦，形长七寸； 齿神峰愕字罗千，形长一寸五分。 已上面部七神，同衣紫衣飞罗裙，并婴儿之形，存之审正罗列一面，各填其官。 按经七名，两眼两耳，其实有九，不如八景，各随其目所处也。 故经云：泥丸九真皆有房，方圆一寸处此中，同服紫衣飞罗裳，此即是前九神也。 若以此语，是九官之九真，则紫衣罗裳不当谬耶。 有意识人，但就此相求，自得天下真伪之病矣。 又云非各别，住俱脑中，而此云罗列一面，又复为乘其发脑眼鼻舌五神长短，皆窃用上景中法。 其耳齿二神，彼既无之，乃虚立寸数，本解斯人那敢如此也。 毕，便叩齿二十四通，咽气十二过，此数又乖七神之理，祝曰： 灵元散气，结气成神，分别前后，总统泥丸，上下相扶，七神敷陈，流形逐变，爱养华源，导引八灵，上冲洞门，卫躯蹑景，上升帝晨。 此祝亦取类八景，且八景之神乃上清中景之法，今乃欲导之，以下御高       耶。 次思心神丹元字守灵，形长九寸，丹锦飞裙； 肺神皓华字虚成，形长八寸，素锦衣裳黄带； 肝神龙烟字含明，形长七寸，青锦帔裳； 肾神玄冥字育婴，形长三寸六分，苍锦衣； 脾神常在字魂庭，形长七寸三分，黄锦衣； 胆神龙曜字威明，形长三寸六分，九色锦衣绿华裙。 此诸衣服悉纯取本经之名，诸神长短亦中景家法，但辄减胆一分，肝一寸，当是欲示其不同。 六府真神处五藏之内六府之宫，按此是列五藏之神，六府止有胆耳。 何谓六府真神，乃言处五藏内耶。 经所言六府，自总举六府之称，本无其神宫之目。 且经又云皆在心内运天经，则不得各在五藏之内，六府之宫。 又经后文重明六处，或神或童，凡有三上三中，各显服色佩带，非尽此五藏之神也。 形如婴儿，色如华童，存之审正，罗列一形，罗列一形，弥乖乎俱在心内者矣。 叩齿二十四通，咽气十二过，祝曰： 五藏六府，真神同归，总御绛宫，上下相随，金房赤子，对处四扉，幽房玄阙，神堂纽机，混化生神，真气精微，保结丹田，与日齐晖，得与八景，合形升飞。 按二十四神，则五藏六府各育有神，今此则藏府相并，谓之同归，於事为乖。 且明堂三老，经皆是显事，中部最为黄庭之主，而今都不存祝，何谓可用存思登虚空耶。 紫微曰：昔孟光诵黄庭，修此道十八年，黄庭真人降之，寻诸仙人男女，无有孟光者，唯梁鸿取妻，号之为孟光耳。 万遍既毕，黄华玉女当告子情。 此黄庭真人，为是何神。
chunks.translated_text:
Upon completing the recitation and concluding the rites and invocations, sit upright facing east, close your eyes, and inwardly visualize the forms, colors, lengths, and sizes of the body’s spirits. Call their names and return them to their respective palaces.

Without practicing this method, even if one recites the scripture ten thousand times, the true spirits will not abide, and no efficacious response will arise. Instead, one will only deplete qi and exhaust the spirits, bringing no benefit to lifespan.

Thus, I have excerpted the essential passages from the scripture to demonstrate them.

The *Yellow Court*’s preface already fully records the methods of recitation. If these two matters remain unpracticed, there will be no efficacious response. Therefore, they must also be explained. Yet the text further discusses methods for averting fear, illness, and encounters with impurity, while entirely omitting the *Spirit Kings*.

Would Master Wang truly not wish to provide clear and precise instructions? Given such omissions in the scripture, the principles remain incomplete, and there is nothing left to cultivate.

Sit upright, close your eyes, and knock the teeth thirty-six times. Then visualize the spirits. Since this is not a grand invocation to suppress evil, the subsequent practice of knocking the teeth thirty-six times (four sets of nine) and visualizing the spirits is absent from the scriptural examples.

The spirit of the hair, *Canghua*, is named *Taiyuan*, two inches and one *fen* in length.
The spirit of the brain, *Jinggen*, is named *Niwan*, one inch and two *fen* in length.
The spirit of the eyes, *Mingshang*, is named *Yingxuan*, three inches in length.
The spirit of the nose, *Yulong*, is named *Lingjian*, two inches and five *fen* in length.
The spirit of the ears, *Kongxian*, is named *Youtian*, three inches and one *fen* in length.
The spirit of the tongue, *Tongming*, is named *Zhenglun*, seven inches in length.
The spirit of the teeth, *Fenge*, is named *Luoqian*, one inch and five *fen* in length.

The seven spirits of the face above all wear purple robes and flying silk skirts, appearing in the form of infants. Visualize them clearly, arranged in order across the face, each returning to its palace.

According to the scripture, there are seven names, but the eyes and ears are paired, making nine in total. This does not align with the *Eight Effulgences*, as each follows its respective location.

Thus, the scripture states: “The Nine Perfected of the *Niwan* all have chambers, each one inch square, dwelling within. Together they wear purple robes and flying silk garments.” These are the nine spirits mentioned earlier.

If this refers to the Nine Perfected of the nine palaces, then the purple robes and silk garments should not be mistaken. Those of discernment need only seek the truth in this, and they will naturally perceive the errors of true and false in the world.

It further states that they do not reside separately but all dwell within the brain, yet here they are described as arranged across the face—this contradicts the lengths of the five spirits of the hair, brain, eyes, nose, and tongue, which are plagiarized from the *Upper Effulgence* method. The spirits of the ears and teeth, which are absent there, are arbitrarily assigned measurements. How could the original author of this explanation dare to do such a thing?

Upon completion, knock the teeth twenty-four times and swallow qi twelve times. These numbers again deviate from the principles of the seven spirits.

Invoke:
“Scattered qi of the numinous origin, coalescing qi to form spirits,
Distinguishing front and back, governing the *Niwan* in unity,
Above and below supporting one another, the seven spirits arrayed,
Flowing forms following transformation, nurturing the source of radiance,
Guiding the eight numina, ascending through the cavernous gate,
Guarding the body, treading the effulgence, ascending to the imperial dawn.”

This invocation is modeled after the *Eight Effulgences*, yet the spirits of the *Eight Effulgences* belong to the *Middle Effulgence* method of the *Shangqing* tradition. How can one now seek to guide them while subordinating the high to the low?

Next, visualize the spirit of the heart, *Danyuan*, named *Shouling*, nine inches in length, wearing a red brocade flying skirt.
The spirit of the lungs, *Haohua*, named *Xucheng*, eight inches in length, dressed in white brocade with a yellow sash.
The spirit of the liver, *Longyan*, named *Hanming*, seven inches in length, wearing a green brocade cloak.
The spirit of the kidneys, *Xuanming*, named *Yuying*, three inches and six *fen* in length, clad in dark brocade.
The spirit of the spleen, *Changzai*, named *Hunting*, seven inches and three *fen* in length, wearing yellow brocade.
The spirit of the gallbladder, *Longyao*, named *Weiming*, three inches and six *fen* in length, dressed in nine-colored brocade with a green floral skirt.

All these garments are derived directly from the names in the original scripture. The lengths of the spirits also follow the *Middle Effulgence* tradition, though the gallbladder is reduced by one *fen* and the liver by one inch, presumably to indicate their difference.

The true spirits of the six bowels reside within the palaces of the five viscera and six bowels. Here, however, only the five viscera’s spirits are listed, with the gallbladder being the sole bowel mentioned. What is meant by “the true spirits of the six bowels residing within the five viscera”?

The scripture’s reference to the six bowels is a general designation, with no specific mention of their spirit-palaces. Moreover, the scripture states that they all circulate the *Heavenly Scripture* within the heart, so they cannot each reside within the palaces of the five viscera and six bowels.

Later in the scripture, the six locations are further clarified—some as spirits, some as youths—with three upper and three middle, each displaying distinct attire and adornments. They are not all confined to the spirits of the five viscera.

Appearing like infants, their colors like radiant youths, visualize them clearly, arranged in order within a single form. Such an arrangement starkly contradicts the claim that they all reside within the heart.

Knock the teeth twenty-four times and swallow qi twelve times. Invoke:
“The five viscera and six bowels, the true spirits return as one,
Together governing the *Crimson Palace*, above and below following,
The golden chamber’s red child, facing the four portals,
The dark chamber’s mysterious gate, the spirit-hall’s pivotal mechanism,
Blending transformation to generate spirits, true qi refined,
Preserving and binding the *Cinnabar Field*, shining with the sun’s radiance,
Attaining union with the *Eight Effulgences*, merging forms to ascend and fly.”

According to the twenty-four spirits, each of the five viscera and six bowels nurtures its own spirit. Here, however, the viscera and bowels are conflated, described as returning as one—this is a contradiction in practice.

Moreover, the *Three Elders of the Hall of Light* are all clearly described in the scripture, with the middle section serving as the primary master of the *Yellow Court*. Yet here, none are visualized or invoked. How can one claim to employ visualization to ascend into the void?

The *Purple Tenuity* states: “In the past, Meng Guang recited the *Yellow Court* and practiced this method for eighteen years. The Perfected of the *Yellow Court* descended to her, but when she sought among the immortals—male and female—there was no Meng Guang. Only Liang Hong’s wife was called Meng Guang.”

After reciting ten thousand times, the *Yellow Flower Jade Maiden* should reveal her feelings to you.

Who, then, is this Perfected of the *Yellow Court*?

chunks.original_text: 若下一元王，宁独降见，而轻立此说，不言今日触纲，将来诸子以为戒此妙极也。 黄庭秘诀尽於此。 形中之神耳，亦可从朝至暮，常思念勿忘，不必待诵经时也，尔其秘之。 右此礼祝，存神两法。 皆想传出，自东晋问并无其书。 假云要秘，观其辞事乖浅，必应是夸竞之徒，傍拟伪经，构造此诀，聊各书录，以旌真伪。 并而论之，前篇礼祝，犹为小胜，此存神之文，牵引冗杂庸陋已甚，疑误后学，其弊不浅。 若以吾所据为非，想诸君可觅真本见示，若必其有者，则吾缄口结舌，终身不复敢言学道也。 入静 正一真人三天法师张讳告南岳夫人口诀。 天师於阳洛教授此诀也。 按夫人于时已就研咏洞经，备行众妙，而方便宣告太清之小术。 民间之验事者云，以夫人在世尝为祭酒故也。 然昔虽为祭酒，於今非复所用，何趣说之。 此既是天师所掌任，夫人又下教之限，故使演出示世，以训正一之官。 且轻位不得教高真，是以显常为祭酒之目，明其有相关处耳。 真人之旨，一句一字，皆有深意在其间焉，精而辩之，乃知其理，徒抱负拜诵，而不能悟寻所析，犹如埋金於土，用比可为。 其入静章奏治病诸法，实亦明威之上典，非悠悠祭酒可使窃闻也。 入静法 此文都不显入静之意，寻其后云，依常旦夕可不事尔者，当是旦夕朝拜，或伏请乞跪，启及章奏，治病之时，先当如此，然后可为诸事也。 按易迁夫人告云，晨夕当心存拜静，似是令用此法，既在疾不堪躬行，故使心存拜耳，今山居在世，亦并可修用，虽自高贵，今率之辞，盖愿今世宦者如此，非谓必是我今岩栖之身也。 若长斋休粮，勤心高业者，可不复身到，而心恭亦当无替，至於后用二朝之法，云当先朝静，乃行此。 按夫人于时尚在，修武何容已究阳洛之义，若此时已受判，后不应更用授判，当别有朝静之法。 世有谷纸古书，云汉中入治朝静法必应是此，但今既幸有所□，便宜用之，又复用汉中法，唯前后祝炉，应小回易其辞耳。 其旦夕入静，则用日出日入时也，日之出入非谓必须见出之与没，尽是出入圆罗之始耳，若有所启请者，当用夜半时也，神理尚幽，故真人下降多不以昼矣。 初入静户之时，当目视香炉，而先心祝曰：南真告云：闭气拜静，使百鬼畏惮，功曹使者龙虎君可见与语，谓能精心久行之耳。 此谓初入便闭气存想，祝炉烧香，通气又闭，而拜祝四方，每一方竟，通气也。 又告：入静户，先右足着前，乃后进左足，令与右足齐，毕乃趋行如故，使人陈启，通达上闻。 此一条恐非唯入东向之静，凡欲启请之处，皆应如此，通幽之事，宜用右足也。 又告：烧香时勿反顾，若反顾则忤真气，致邪应也。 此谓既入静，不得复转头后顾。 若回行正向看外，亦当无嫌。 此二朝后，又云：出静户之时，不得反顾，如反顾则忤真光，致不诚。 如此出入静户并不可反顾也。 又云：入静户不得唤外人，及他所言念，又入户出户，皆云漱口。 寻此之旨，凡静中吏司，皆泰清官寮，纠察严明，殊多科制，若不如法，非但无感，亦即致咎祸害者矣。 今谨述入静次第，立成之法如左：先盥澡东带，刷头理发，裙褐整事，巾履斋洁，两手执笏，不得以纸缠裹，既至户外，嗽口三遍，仍闭气，举右足入户，次进左足，使并进前平立，正心临目，存直使、正一功曹、左右官使者四人，并在户内两边侧立，又龙君在左，虎君在右，捧香使者二人，侠侍香炉，守静玉女侠侍案几，都毕，乃通气，开目正视香炉，乃心祝曰：
chunks.translated_text:
Should the *Primordial Sovereign of the Lower Realm* deign to descend and appear alone, how could one lightly establish such a doctrine? To speak thus today is to entangle the net of principles—may future disciples take this as a profound warning. Here ends the secret transmission of the *Yellow Court*.

The spirits within the body may be contemplated from dawn to dusk, ever held in mind without forgetfulness; one need not wait for the recitation of scripture. Guard this well.

The rites of obeisance and the two methods of spirit visualization recorded here were both transmitted through mental transmission. From the Eastern Jin onward, no written record of them has existed. If secrecy were truly required, the crudeness and shallowness of these words and matters would reveal them as the fabrications of boastful and competitive impostors, who cobbled together this spurious scripture. I have recorded them here merely to distinguish truth from falsehood.

Comparing the two, the earlier section on rites of obeisance is slightly superior, while this text on spirit visualization is so convoluted, redundant, and vulgar as to risk misleading later students—its harm is not insignificant. If my judgment here is deemed incorrect, I invite all to seek out the authentic text and present it. Should such a text indeed exist, I shall seal my lips and bind my tongue, never again daring to speak of the study of the Dao.

---

**Entering Stillness**
Oral transmission from the *Orthodox Unity Perfected Realized One*, the *Three Heavens Master* Zhang [Daoling], to the *Lady of Southern Marchmount*.

When the *Celestial Master* taught this transmission in Yangluo, the Lady had already immersed herself in the recitation of the *Cavern Scriptures* and mastered the manifold subtleties. Yet he still condescended to impart this minor art of the *Great Clarity*. Some in the world claim this was because the Lady had once served as a *Libationer*—but though she once held that office, it is no longer relevant today. Why then speak of it?

Since this transmission was entrusted to the *Celestial Master*, and the Lady was bound by the duty to instruct those below, it was set forth for the world to guide the officials of *Orthodox Unity*. Moreover, those of low rank may not instruct the lofty perfected; thus, the title of *Libationer* is explicitly retained to clarify its connection.

Every word and phrase of the *Perfected Realized One* carries profound meaning. Only through meticulous discernment can one grasp its principles. Merely reciting and bowing without seeking to comprehend its divisions is like burying gold in the earth—what use is that?

The chapter on *Entering Stillness* and the methods for memorializing and treating illness are indeed among the highest canons of solemn authority, not to be casually overheard by careless *Libationers*.

---

**Method of Entering Stillness**
This text does not clearly state the meaning of *entering stillness*. Later, it mentions that one may dispense with ordinary morning and evening practices, suggesting that these refer to morning and evening obeisances, prostrations, supplications, or the submission of memorials. When treating illness, one should first perform these rites before proceeding with other matters.

According to the transmission from *Lady Yi Qian*, one should "morning and evening hold the heart in reverent stillness." This seems to prescribe the use of this method. If illness prevents physical performance, one may instead hold the heart in reverent stillness. Even those dwelling in mountains or living in the world may practice this. Though the language here is humble, it is intended for officials of this age, not necessarily for those who now dwell in mountain retreats.

Those who maintain long fasts and abstain from grains, devoting themselves to lofty practices, need not physically attend but should hold their hearts in reverence without fail. As for the later method of the *Two Audiences*, it states that one should first perform the *Audience of Stillness* before proceeding. At the time, the Lady was still alive; how could she have already exhausted the teachings of Yangluo? If she had already received the *Judgment*, she should not have used it again later—there must have been a separate method for the *Audience of Stillness*.

There exists an ancient text on *Grain Paper* from Hanzhong, titled *Method of Entering Governance and Audience of Stillness*, which likely refers to this. Since we are now fortunate to possess this [transmission], we should employ it. If one also uses the Hanzhong method, only the words of the opening and closing incense rites need slight adjustment.

For morning and evening *entering stillness*, use the times of sunrise and sunset. These are not the moments when the sun is seen to rise or set, but rather the beginning of its passage through the *Circular Net*. If making a petition, use the hour of midnight, for the workings of the spirits are profound, and the *Perfected Realized One* rarely descends during the day.

When first entering the chamber of stillness, gaze at the incense burner and silently recite: The *Southern Perfected* said: "Hold the breath and bow in stillness, so that the hundred ghosts stand in awe. The *Merit Officers* and *Messengers*, the *Dragon* and *Tiger Lords*, may then appear and speak with you." This refers to holding the breath and visualizing at the outset, then reciting the incense prayer, exhaling, holding the breath again, and bowing to the four directions. After each direction, exhale.

It is further instructed: When entering the chamber of stillness, first step forward with the right foot, then bring the left foot forward to align with it. Only then proceed as usual, so that one’s petition may be clearly heard above.

This instruction likely applies not only to entering the eastern-facing chamber of stillness but to all places of petition. For matters of communicating with the unseen, the right foot should lead.

It is also said: When burning incense, do not look back, for to do so would offend the *true qi* and invite demonic responses. This means that once inside the chamber of stillness, one must not turn the head to look behind. However, if one turns to face outward directly, there should be no harm.

After the *Two Audiences*, it is again stated: When exiting the chamber of stillness, do not look back, for to do so would offend the *true light* and invite insincerity. Thus, both entering and exiting the chamber of stillness forbid looking back.

It is further said: Do not call out to those outside or speak of other matters while in the chamber. Both entering and exiting require rinsing the mouth.

The intent here is that all officials and attendants within the chamber of stillness belong to the *Supreme Clarity* bureaucracy, where scrutiny is strict and regulations numerous. Failure to comply not only prevents resonance but may also invite misfortune and harm.

Now, I set forth the proper sequence for *entering stillness* as follows:

First, bathe and bind the sash to the east, comb the hair, arrange the garments, and ensure the headcloth and shoes are pure. Hold the tablet in both hands, without wrapping it in paper. Upon reaching the chamber door, rinse the mouth three times, hold the breath, step forward with the right foot, then bring the left foot forward to align with it, and stand evenly. Calm the heart and direct the gaze inward, visualizing the *Straightforward Messenger*, the *Orthodox Unity Merit Officers*, and the *Left and Right Official Messengers*—four in total—standing to either side within the chamber. The *Dragon Lord* stands to the left, the *Tiger Lord* to the right, with two *Incense-Bearing Messengers* flanking the incense burner, and the *Jade Maiden Guardians of Stillness* attending the desk. Once all are visualized, exhale, open the eyes, gaze directly at the incense burner, and silently recite:

The Perfected of the *Yellow Court* descended to her, but when she sought among the immortals—male and female—there was no Meng Guang. Only Liang Hong’s wife was called Meng Guang.”

chunks.original_text: 太上玄元五灵老君，当召功曹使者，左右龙虎君，捧香使者，三炁正神，行二朝者，当益云及侍经神童玉女。 急上关启三天太上玄元道君，奏闻上清宫。 某正尔烧香，入静朝神，奉行东华秘法，以某本命日去某本命九十日平旦，入静朝太微天帝君。 又以某生日去某生月一百八十二日夜半，入静朝太上高圣君。 乞得八方正气，来入某身，所启速闻径达帝前。 太微天帝君玉阙紫宫前，太上高圣君琼阙下。 毕，乃烧香行事，通气，先进右足至炉前，左足来并，左手三捻香，多烧之。 按二朝既云先朝静，朝静祝炉之辞，不容止依朝静，故宜随事增损，粗如前朱注，以递互回换用之。 烧香毕，先退右足，左还并，视烟起闭气，乃拜也。 初向再拜。 此既谓之拜静，静法自应东向，初入祝炉便是向西，故不复云西向耳。 此当正静屋中央，安一方机，一香炉，一香厱，四面向之。 后云若因病入静，四面烧香，安四香炉者，当安四香机着四边，各勿至壁，己入中央，以次拜祝。 初入祝炉仍於户内，通向西并祝祝之，乃入中四面烧香也，毕亦西向一祝耳。 若经堂中南向屋者，自不得用此法，且亦无功曹龙虎，正有侍经神童玉女耳。 若朝太上太素午达者，自可止经堂中。 凡旦夕拜静竟，亦又还经前，更烧香请乞众真，求长生所愿者，其余章奏请天帝君，请官治病，灭祸祈福，皆於静中矣。 拜讫，三自搏，四拜毕。 跪故笏於前，两手自搏，及更执笏，称男女姓名，谨关启云，余方皆效此也。 谨关启天师、女师系师三师，门下典者君吏，愿得正一三炁，灌养形神，使五藏生华，六府宣通，为消四方之灾祸，解七世之殃患，长生久视，得为飞仙。 毕又再拜。 汉代以前亦复应有天师，皆应有三人，亦有一女，但未必是夫妻父子耳。 正一之气，以师为本，故先拜请，乃北向耳。 初再拜自搏，举哀矜也，后又再拜，谢恩德也，诸例中拜有先后者，事旨皆如斯矣。 次北向再拜讫，三自搏，曰： 谨关启上皇太上北上大道君，某以胎生肉人，枯骨子孙，愿得除七世以来，下及某身，千罪万过，阴伏匿恶，考犯三官者，皆令消解，当令福生五方，祸灭九阴，邪精百鬼，莫敢当向，存思神仙，玉女来降，长生久视，寿同三光。 毕，又再拜。 北上道君，太清之真最贵者也，故礼师竟，便拜之。 次东向再拜，讫三自搏，曰： 谨关启太清玄元无上三天无极大道、太上老君、太上丈人、天帝君、天帝丈人、九老仙都君、九炁丈人，百千万重道炁，千二百官君，太清玉陛下，当令某心开意悟，耳目聪明，万仙会议，赐以玉丹，消灾却祸，遂获神仙，世宦高贵，金车入门，口舌恶祸，千殃万患，一时灭绝，记在三官，被受三天丈人之恩。 毕又再拜。 此太清诸官君，三天之正任，主掌兆民祸福所由，故次拜之。 次南向再拜讫，三自搏曰： 谨关启南上大道君，乞得书名神仙玉籍，告诸司命，以长生为定。 又勅三天万福君，令致四方财宝，八方之谷帛，富积巍巍，施行功德，所向所欲，万事成克，如心所愿，如手所指，长生神仙，寿同天地。 此生字，本作久字，后人改为生，今当从真为长久也。 毕又再拜。 此太清，南方之道君耳，位劣於北上，故元上皇太上之号，是以最后拜之，可命有三十六人，此为诸下小者耳。
chunks.translated_text:
The Most High Mysterious Origin Five Numinous Venerable Lord, summon the Merit Officers and Messengers, the Left and Right Dragon and Tiger Lords, the Incense-Bearing Messengers, the Three Qi Orthodox Spirits, and those who perform the Two Audiences—may clouds gather and the Scripture-Attending Divine Lads and Jade Maidens draw near.

Hasten to report to the Three Heavens’ Most High Mysterious Origin Dao Lord, and memorialize the Supreme Clarity Palace. I now burn incense, enter stillness, and present myself before the spirits, practicing the Eastern Florescence esoteric method. From the ninetieth day after my life-origin day, at dawn, I enter stillness to present myself before the Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity. From the one hundred eighty-second day after my birth month, at midnight, I enter stillness to present myself before the Most High Lofty Sage Lord. May the Eight Directions’ Orthodox Qi enter my body, and may my petition swiftly ascend to the presence of the Emperor.

Before the Jade Tower and Purple Palace of the Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity, beneath the Jasper Tower of the Most High Lofty Sage Lord.

Once done, burn incense and proceed. Exhale, advance the right foot to the incense burner, then bring the left foot forward to align with it. With the left hand, take three pinches of incense and burn them abundantly. As the Two Audiences are said to begin with silent audience, the incantation at the incense burner should not be limited to the silent audience but adapted to the occasion, roughly following the vermilion annotations for alternating use.

After burning the incense, first withdraw the right foot, then bring the left foot back to align with it. Observe the rising smoke, hold the breath, and bow. Initially, bow twice. This is called the Bow of Stillness, and the method of stillness naturally requires facing east. Upon first entering and reciting at the incense burner, one faces west, so it is not reiterated here.

Place a square mat in the center of the stillness chamber, with one incense burner and one incense box, facing all four directions. Later, if entering stillness due to illness, burn incense in all four directions, arranging four incense burners. Place four incense mats at the four sides, each not touching the walls. Enter the center and bow in sequence. Upon first entering, recite at the incense burner within the chamber, facing west. Then enter the center and burn incense in all four directions, concluding with a single recitation facing west.

If the scripture hall faces south, this method cannot be used, and there are no Merit Officers, Dragon or Tiger Lords—only the Scripture-Attending Divine Lads and Jade Maidens. If presenting oneself before the Most High Primordial Noon Attainment, one may remain in the scripture hall.

After completing the dawn and dusk Bows of Stillness, return before the scriptures, burn incense again, and invoke the host of Perfected Ones, seeking immortality and the fulfillment of wishes. Other petitions to the Celestial Emperor, requests to officials for healing, disaster eradication, or blessings—all are conducted within stillness.

After bowing, strike the chest three times, then bow four times in total. Kneel and place the tablet before oneself. Strike the chest with both hands, then take up the tablet again, stating one’s name (male or female), and solemnly report:

I humbly report to the Heavenly Master, the Female Master, and the Lineage Master—the Three Masters—and to the Attending Officers and Clerks of the Gate. May I receive the Orthodox Unity Three Qi to nourish my form and spirit, causing the Five Viscera to flourish and the Six Palaces to flow freely. May the disasters of the four directions be dispelled, the calamities of seven generations dissolved, and may I attain long life and enduring vision, becoming a flying immortal.

Conclude with two more bows. Before the Han dynasty, there were also Heavenly Masters—likely three in number, including one woman, though not necessarily kin.

The Orthodox Unity Qi is rooted in the Master, so one first bows and invokes them, then faces north. The initial two bows with chest-striking express grief and supplication; the subsequent two bows express gratitude for virtue. In all such cases, the order of bowing follows the intent of the matter.

Next, face north and bow twice, striking the chest three times, and say:

I humbly report to the Supreme August Most High Northern Great Dao Lord. I, a flesh-born mortal and withered-bone descendant, beseech the erasure of the thousand sins and myriad transgressions—hidden evils and offenses against the Three Officials—accumulated from seven generations past to my present self. May fortune arise in the five directions, calamities vanish in the nine yin, and no hundred ghosts or wayward spirits dare oppose me. May I envision divine immortals and jade maidens descending, attaining long life and enduring vision, my lifespan equaling the Three Luminaries.

Conclude with two more bows. The Northern Great Dao Lord is the most exalted Perfected of the Grand Clarity, so one bows to them after paying respects to the Master.

Next, face east and bow twice, striking the chest three times, and say:

I humbly report to the Grand Clarity Mysterious Origin Most High Three Heavens Boundless Great Dao, the Most High Venerable Lord, the Most High Elder, the Celestial Emperor, the Celestial Elder, the Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital, the Nine Qi Elder, the myriad layers of Dao Qi, the Twelve Hundred Official Lords, and the Jade Court of the Grand Clarity. May my heart open and my mind awaken, my ears and eyes grow keen, and the myriad immortals convene in council to bestow upon me the Jade Elixir. May disasters be dispelled, calamities averted, and immortality attained. May my worldly rank be noble, golden chariots enter my gate, and all slanderous misfortunes—thousands of calamities and myriad afflictions—be eradicated at once. May my record in the Three Offices be expunged, and may I receive the grace of the Three Heavens’ Elder.

Conclude with two more bows. These Grand Clarity Official Lords govern the fortunes and misfortunes of all beings as the rightful stewards of the Three Heavens, so one bows to them next.

Next, face south and bow twice, striking the chest three times, and say:

I humbly report to the Southern Great Dao Lord. May my name be inscribed in the Jade Register of Divine Immortals and announced to the various Lords of Destiny, securing long life as my fate. May the Ten Thousand Blessings Lord of the Three Heavens be commanded to bring treasures from the four directions and silks and grains from the eight, amassing boundless wealth. May my meritorious deeds be enacted, all endeavors succeed, and every wish be fulfilled as if by the work of my own hands. May I attain long life and immortality, my lifespan equaling heaven and earth.

[Note: The character *sheng* (生) was originally *jiu* (久), later altered to *sheng*; here, it should follow the original meaning of "long-lasting."]

Conclude with two more bows. This is the Grand Clarity’s Southern Dao Lord, whose rank is inferior to the Northern Great Dao Lord, hence lacking the august title of Supreme August Most High. Thus, one bows to them last. There are thirty-six such Lords, and this one ranks among the lesser.

chunks.original_text: 此万福君犹是官将，主财宝者。 千二百官仪第七卷之十五云：无上万福吏二十八人，官将百二十人，主来五方利，金银钱绢布帛丝绵谷米，所思立至，黄生主之。 又第三之十三，亦有万福君五人，官将百二十人，主辟斥故气精祟注气，却死来生，却祸来福，所思者至。 都讫。 或四向叩头者，却祸来福，所思随意也。 叩头例，施於有急疾患之时，依常旦夕可不事尔。 四向叩头者，当先朝启一方竟，仍叩头，又自搏，言今所乞，亦可脱巾悲泣，在事之缓急耳。 竟又再拜。 余方皆如此。

This Lord of Myriad Blessings is still but an official-general, one who presides over treasures and wealth. The fifteenth scroll of the seventh fascicle of the *Rites of the Twelve Hundred Offices* states: "There are twenty-eight Supreme Myriad Blessings Clerks and one hundred twenty official-generals, who govern the five directional benefits—gold, silver, coins, silks, cloth, silk floss, grains, and rice—ensuring that whatever is desired arrives at once. These are overseen by Huang Sheng."

Additionally, the thirteenth scroll of the third fascicle records five Lords of Myriad Blessings and one hundred twenty official-generals, who dispel stale qi, essence-wraiths, and afflicting qi, averting death and summoning life, turning misfortune into fortune, and bringing whatever is desired to fruition.

This concludes the rite.

If one bows in the four directions, it serves to avert misfortune and summon fortune, with all desires fulfilled as wished. The practice of bowing in the four directions is typically employed in times of urgent illness or distress; under ordinary circumstances at dawn and dusk, it need not be performed.

When bowing in the four directions, one should first face and invoke one direction, then bow, and further strike one’s breast, declaring one’s present entreaty. One may also remove one’s headscarf and weep bitterly, depending on the urgency of the matter. Once finished, bow twice more. The same procedure applies to the remaining directions.

chunks.original_text: 都讫，更东向烧香，口启请官，救解今患，悉依后法也。 并皆微言，其旦夕拜礼，如前自足。 临出静户，正向香炉而微祝曰：还西向闭气，视炉而微祝。 初曰心祝，今曰微祝，当小小动口也。 香官使者，左右龙虎君，当令静室忽有芝草，金液丹精，百灵交会在此香火前，使张甲张者称姓，甲者称名，前单云某，直称名耳。 得道之气，获长生神仙，举家万福，若山居绝累者，云山舍万福。 大小受恩，守静四面玉女，二朝时并云及侍经神童玉女，并侍卫火烟，书记某所言，径入三天门玉帝几前。 二朝云上清官太微天帝道君几前，上清上宫太上高圣玉晨道君几前。 乃出户。 於户内仍漱口，先举左足出，乃次右足，勿反顾。 都毕。 若疾急，他有所陈，自随事续后而言之任意也。 皆当微言，勿令声大。 具如前注。 汉中入治朝静法
chunks.translated_text:
Having concluded the rite, turn to face east and burn incense, invoking the officials to beseech deliverance from present afflictions, all in accordance with the methods described below. Speak softly in all cases, and the dawn and dusk bowing rituals remain as previously sufficient.

Before exiting the chamber of stillness, stand directly before the incense burner and utter a whispered prayer. Then turn west, hold the breath, gaze upon the burner, and whisper the prayer again. The initial prayer is called the "prayer of the heart," while this is termed the "whispered prayer," requiring only the slightest movement of the lips.

O Fragrant Officials and Envoys, Lords of the Left and Right Dragon-Tiger, may this chamber of stillness suddenly manifest auspicious herbs, golden elixir and cinnabar essence, with a hundred spirits converging before this fragrant flame. Let Zhang of Jia state his surname, and Jia state his given name; if only a single name is provided, simply declare it as such.

May the qi of attaining the Dao grant transcendence as a divine immortal, bringing ten thousand blessings to the entire household. For those dwelling in mountain retreats far from worldly burdens, say: "May the mountain abode receive ten thousand blessings." May all, great and small, receive grace, and may the jade maidens guarding the four directions in stillness—along with the jade maidens attending the scriptures and the divine youths at the two audiences—together with the guardians of the fragrant smoke, record these words of mine and transmit them directly to the jade throne before the Jade Emperor at the Gate of the Three Heavens.

At the two audiences, speak also of the jade throne before the Heavenly Emperor of the Dao Lord in the Supreme Clarity Palace of the Grand Tenuity Heaven, and the jade throne before the Most High and Sagely Jade Dawn Dao Lord in the Supreme Palace of Supreme Clarity.

Then exit the chamber. Within the doorway, rinse the mouth, first stepping out with the left foot, then the right, without looking back. The rite is complete.

If the affliction is urgent or other matters require petition, proceed as the situation demands, appending them afterward as one sees fit. In all cases, speak softly, ensuring the voice does not rise. All follows as previously annotated. This is the method of entering governance through stillness and audience, as practiced in Hanzhong.

chunks.original_text: 先东向云：甲贪生乐活，愿从诸君丈人，乞丐长存久视，延年益寿，得为种民，与天地相守。 当使甲家灾祸消灭，百病自愈，神明附身，心开意悟。 次北向：甲欲改恶为善，愿从太玄上一君乞丐原赦罪过，解除基谪，度脱灾难，辟斥县官。 当令甲所向，金石为开，水火为灭，恶逆宾伏，精邪消散。 次西向：甲好道乐仙，愿从天师乞丐所乐者得，所作者成。 当使甲心开意解，耳目聪明，百病消除，身体轻强。 次南向：甲修身养性，还年却老，愿从道德君乞丐恩润之气布施骨体，使道气流行，甲身咸蒙慈恩，众病消除，福吉来集。 思在万福君为甲致四方钱财，治生进利，所向皆至。 四方朝文如此，是为右行法，与紫门所说同，而无先后，祝炉文所於四方所请，大意略同，而质略不及后□者。 章符 若急事上章，当用朱笔题署。 谓卒有暴疾病，及祸难忧惧急事，请后天昌君等上章，乞救解者，当朱书太清玄都正一平炁系天师某、治炁祭酒，臣某，又后太清细字，并臣姓所属，及太岁日月以下三天曹，得此朱署即奏闻。 犹如今阳官，赤标符为急事也。 若欲上逐鬼章，当朱书所上祭酒姓名。 谓家有恶强之鬼为祸祟，请后右仙食气君将等为逐却之，上章者不以朱题署，止书为上章人某治祭酒甲，又后姓某耳。 若欲上治邪病章，当用青纸。 三官主邪君吏，贵青色也。 谓人有淫邪之气，及诸庙座邪鬼为患，请后平天君等消制之，上章者当以朱书青纸章也，亦可别脆青纸，随人多少。 若注气鬼病，当作击鬼章。 谓家有五墓考讼死丧逆注之鬼来为病害，宜攻击消散，请后四胡高仓君将等，上章毕者，合捣之服之，如后法也。 上章毕，用真朱二分，古秤即今之一两也。 合已上之章，於臼中捣之，和以蜜成丸，分作细丸，顿服之。 用平旦时，入静北向再拜服之。 垂死者皆活。 勿令人知捣合之时也，使病者魂神正，鬼气不敢干，他病亦可为之也。 若病者能自捣和为佳，不尔即上章祭酒为捣之，先以蜜渍纸令软，烂乃捣为丸。 此章自不过两纸，所丸亦无多，必应一过顿服，以清水送之，不得分为两三也。 云余病亦可为者，则不止於击鬼也。 上章当别有笔砚以书，不得杂也。 墨亦异之。 此笔砚若是写经常冷用者，共之无嫌，自不得与世中书疏同耳。 左行摩墨四十九过止，重摩墨亦四十九转。 左行如星次向东也。 重摩墨者，谓程墨时四十九过，以法大衍圆蓍之数，故能通幽达神者矣。 此一条使人学道之意弥精贯毫厘，动有法象，岂得为尔泛泛耶。 书章时烧香，向北书之。 当别用好纸笔，巾案触物皆使洁冷，东带恭坐，谨正书治，踈概墨色皆令调好，面糊函封依法奏上。 案今所应上章，并无正定好本，多是凡校，祭酒虚加损益，永不可承用。 唯当依千二百官仪注，取所请官并此二十四官与事目相应者。 请之先自申陈疾患根源，次谢愆考罹咎，乃请官救解，每使省哀。 若应有酬脆金青纸油等物，皆条牒多少，注诏所吏兵之号，不得混漫。 章中无的奉，若口启亦然。 其悬脆者，须事效即送，登即呈启所之物，皆分奉所禀天师，及施散山栖学士，或供道用所须，勿以自私赡衣食，三官考察，非小事也。 按小君言，人家有疾病死丧，衰厄光怪，梦寤钱财减耗，可以禳厌，唯应分解冢讼墓注为急，不能解释，祸方未已。
chunks.translated_text:
First face east and declare: "May I, Jia, rejoice in life and delight in vitality. I humbly beseech the Lords and Elders of all directions to grant me long life and enduring vision, to prolong my years and augment my longevity, that I may become one of the seed-people and abide with Heaven and Earth. May the disasters and misfortunes of Jia’s household be dispelled, all illnesses healed of themselves, divine luminaries attach to my body, and my heart open with enlightened understanding."

Next face north: "I, Jia, desire to turn from evil toward goodness. I humbly beseech the Supreme Mystery’s Most Exalted One to pardon my transgressions, absolve my karmic retributions, deliver me from calamities, and repel the clutches of worldly authorities. May all I face yield like metal and stone, water and fire be extinguished, malevolent rebels submit, and pernicious spirits disperse."

Then face west: "I, Jia, delight in the Dao and rejoice in immortality. I humbly beseech the Heavenly Master to grant what I desire and fulfill what I undertake. May my heart open and understanding deepen, my ears and eyes grow keen, all illnesses vanish, and my body become light and strong."

Finally face south: "I, Jia, cultivate the body and nurture my nature, seeking to return to youth and reverse aging. I humbly beseech the Lord of Virtue and Dao to bestow the qi of gracious moisture upon my bones and frame, that the qi of the Dao may flow freely. May my entire being be enveloped in compassionate favor, all illnesses dispelled, and blessings and fortune gather. I entreat the Lord of Myriad Fortunes to bring wealth from all directions, advancing my livelihood and increasing my gains, that all I pursue may come to fruition."

This is the text for the four directional audiences, known as the *Rightward Progression Method*, identical to that described in the Purple Gate, though without prescribed sequence. The prayers at the incense burner for the four directions share a similar essence, though their substance is somewhat less refined than what follows.

**Petitions and Talismans**
For urgent matters requiring a petition, use cinnabar to inscribe the heading. In cases of sudden illness, disaster, or pressing concerns—such as invoking the Heavenly Prosperity Lord and others to submit a petition for deliverance—write in cinnabar: "By the authority of the Orthodox Unity of the Great Clarity, the Celestial Master [Name], the Master of Qi and Libationer, your servant [Name]." Below, in smaller script, add the servant’s surname and affiliation, followed by the year, month, and day under the Three Heavenly Bureaus. Once this cinnabar heading is affixed, the petition may be submitted. This is akin to the red-marked talismans used by officials for urgent matters today.

To submit a petition for expelling ghosts, inscribe the name of the libationer to whom it is addressed. For households plagued by malevolent and powerful ghosts, invoke the Rightward Immortal Lord of Aerial Qi and others to drive them away. The petitioner need not use cinnabar for the heading but may simply write: "Submitted by Libationer [Name] of [Place], your servant [Surname]."

For petitions to treat demonic illnesses, use blue paper, as the Three Officials’ demon-quelling officers favor this color. For afflictions caused by licentious or demonic qi, or by spirits haunting temples and shrines, invoke the Heavenly Equilibrium Lord and others to subdue them. The petition should be written in cinnabar on blue paper, which may be cut into strips according to the number of copies needed.

For illnesses caused by qi-inflicting ghosts, compose a *Striking Ghost Petition*. For households troubled by vengeful ghosts from ancestral tombs, litigation, or untimely deaths, invoke the Four Hu Generals of the High Granary and others to attack and disperse them. Once the petition is complete, grind it with two *fen* of pure cinnabar (equivalent to one modern *liang*). Combine the ground petition with honey to form pills, which should be taken all at once in the early morning while facing north after bowing twice. Even those on the brink of death may be revived. The grinding and mixing must be done in secret, lest the patient’s hun-soul be disturbed and ghostly qi dare to interfere. This method may also be applied to other illnesses.

If the patient is capable, they should grind and mix the pills themselves; otherwise, the libationer submitting the petition may do so. First soak the paper in honey to soften it, then grind it thoroughly into pills. The petition itself should not exceed two sheets, and the resulting pills will not be numerous. They must be taken in one dose, washed down with clear water, and not divided into multiple servings. While this method is particularly effective for striking ghosts, it may also be used for other ailments.

When composing a petition, use separate brushes and inkstones, avoiding contamination. Even the ink should be distinct. However, brushes and inkstones used for copying scriptures may be shared without issue, provided they are not used for mundane correspondence.

When grinding ink, rotate the inkstick counterclockwise forty-nine times and stop. Repeat the grinding process forty-nine times. The counterclockwise motion follows the celestial sequence, beginning in the east. The number forty-nine corresponds to the *Dayan* method of divination with milfoil stalks, enabling communication with the unseen and the divine. This practice reflects the meticulous precision required in Daoist study, where every action aligns with cosmic patterns—far from being a casual endeavor.

When writing a petition, burn incense and face north. Use fine paper and brushes, ensuring all utensils—cloths, desks, and other implements—are clean and cool. Wear the sash on the left, sit reverently, and write with care. The ink’s consistency and the brush’s strokes should be well-balanced. Seal the petition in an envelope with paste and submit it according to the proper method.

Currently, there is no standardized template for petitions, and many are carelessly edited by libationers, rendering them unreliable for use. One should adhere to the *Rituals of the Twelve Hundred Officials*, selecting the appropriate deities from the twenty-four officials based on the matter at hand. Begin by detailing the root of the affliction, then confess transgressions and acknowledge faults before invoking the officials for deliverance, keeping the tone humble. If offerings such as gold foil, blue paper, or oil are required, specify the quantities and list the names of the summoned officers and soldiers, avoiding ambiguity. The petition should not include vague promises of offerings; the same applies to verbal declarations.

For suspended offerings, deliver them promptly upon the resolution of the matter, presenting the specified items. These offerings should be distributed to the Celestial Master, dispersed among mountain-dwelling scholars, or used for Daoist purposes. They must not be appropriated for personal use, such as clothing or food, as the Three Officials scrutinize such matters closely.

According to the Lesser Lord, for households experiencing illness, death, misfortune, strange phenomena, disturbing dreams, or financial decline, exorcism may be performed. However, the most urgent matters requiring resolution are ancestral tomb disputes and grave-related afflictions. Failure to address these will ensure the continuation of misfortune.
